{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | image = | name = Jan Trefulka | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|5|15}} | birth_place = [[Brno]], [[Czechoslovakia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|11|22|1929|5|15}} | death_place = Brno, [[Czech Republic]] | occupation = Writer | nationality = [[Czech Republic|Czech]] | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | debut_works = | influences = | influenced = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Jan Trefulka''' (15 May 1929 – 22 November 2012) was a Czech writer, translator, literary critic and publicist.
==Biography== Trefulka was born in Brno, [[Czech Republic]], where he also died.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/czech-writer-dissident-jan-trefulka-dies/869256|title=Czech writer, dissident Jan Trefulka dies|publisher=[[Czech News Agency]]|date=22 November 2012|accessdate=22 November 2012}}</ref> He attended school with [[Milan Kundera]] and the pair remained lifelong friends.
Critical of the [[communist]] regime, in 1950 he was expelled from the [[Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia|Czechoslovakian Communist Party]] for "anti-party activities" along with Kundera. At the same time he was expelled from [[Charles University]] in [[Prague]] where he was studying [[literature]] and [[aesthetics]]. Trefulka wrote about his run-in with the communist party in his first novella ''Pršelo jim štestí'' (Happiness Rained on Them, [[1962 in literature|1962]]). Trefulka was involved with [[Samizdat]] - the publishing and distributing of censored literature under communist rule, and was a signatory of [[Charter 77]].
Trefulka found it difficult to find work in the country after the [[Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia|Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia]] in 1968. He spent time unemployed and working as a manual labourer.
After the [[Velvet Revolution]] and the downfall of the communist regime in 1989, he became more active in public life, becoming president of the Association of Moravian-Silesian Writers and a member of the first Czech Television Council.
==List of works== * ''Happiness Rained on Them'' (''Pršelo jim štěstí'') (1962) * ''Praise Only for the Fools'' (''O bláznech jen dobré'') (1973) * ''The Criminal Uprising'' (''Zločin pozdvižen'') (1978) * ''Seduced and Betrayed'' (''Svedený a opuštěný'') (1983) * ''A Fool's Reader'' (''Bláznova čítanka'') (1998) A collection of Trefulka's work published in Samizdat.
==References== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=a52DF0aGtisC&pg=PA135 ''A Handbook of Czech Prose Writing, 1940-2005'' B. R. Bradbrook on 'Google Books' website] * [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=cs&u=http://www.atlantis-brno.cz/inshop/autori/trefulka-jan/&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=5&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3Djan%2Btrefulka%26hl%3Den translated 'Atlantis' website] * [https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=cs&u=http://www.spisovatele.cz/jan-trefulka&sa=X&oi=translate&resnum=2&ct=result&prev=/search%3Fq%3Djan%2Btrefulka%26start%3D10%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DN translated 'Spisovatelé' website] <references /> * [http://baila.net/autor/31093696/jan-trefulka Jan Trefulka at Czechoslovak book network Baila.net]
{{Authority control}}

[[File:File Jean-Étienne-Marie Portalis (1915).jpg|thumb]] '''Jean-Étienne-Marie Portalis''' (1 April 1746 – 25 August 1807) was a French [[jurist]] and politician in time of the [[French Revolution]] and the [[First French Empire|First Empire]]. His son, [[Joseph Marie Portalis]], was a diplomat and statesman.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Portalis was born at [[Le Beausset]], currently in the [[Var (département)|Var]] [[Département in France|département]] of [[Provence]], [[France]] to a [[bourgeois]] family, and was educated by the [[Oratory of Saint Philip Neri|Oratorians]] at their schools in [[Toulon]] and [[Marseille]], and then went to the [[Paul Cézanne University|University of Aix]]. As a student, he published his first two works, ''Observations sur Émile'' (on [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau]]'s ''[[Emile: Or, On Education]]'') in 1763 and ''Des Préjugés'' in 1764.
In 1765 he became a [[lawyer]] at the ''[[parlement]]'' of [[Aix-en-Provence]], and soon obtained so great a reputation that he was instructed by [[Étienne François, duc de Choiseul|Étienne François de Choiseul]] in 1770 to draw up the decree authorizing the marriage of [[Protestant]]s. From 1778 to 1781, Portalis was one of the four ''[[assessor (law)|assessor]]s'' or administrators of Provence.
===Revolution=== In November 1793, after the [[First French Republic]] had been proclaimed, he came to [[Paris]] and was thrown into prison for being the brother-in-law of [[Joseph Jérôme, comte Siméon|Joseph Jérôme Siméon]], the leader of the [[Girondist|Federalists]] in Provence. He was soon released to a ''[[Psychiatric hospital|maison de santé]]'', where he remained until the fall of [[Maximilien Robespierre]] during the [[Thermidorian Reaction]].
On being released he practised as a lawyer in Paris, and, in 1795, he was elected by the capital to the [[Council of Ancients]] of the [[French Directory]], becoming a leader of the moderate party opposed to the directory rule. As a leader of the moderates, he was targeted by the ''[[coup d'état]]'' of 18 Fructidor, but, unlike General [[Charles Pichegru]] and [[François Barbé-Marbois]], he managed to escape to [[Switzerland]], then to [[Holstein]], and did not return until after [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon Bonaparte]] established himself as the leader of the new [[French Consulate|Consulate]].
===Under Napoleon=== Bonaparte made him a ''[[Council of State (France)|conseiller d'état]]'' in 1800, and then charged him, with [[François Denis Tronchet]], [[Félix-Julien-Jean Bigot de Préameneu]], and [[Jacques de Maleville]], to draw up the ''[[Napoleonic code|Code Civil]]''. Of this commission he was the most notable member, and many of the most important titles, notably those on marriage and [[Inheritance|heirship]], are his work. He gave a famous speech, "Discours préliminaire au projet de code civil" in which he presented the core principles of the civil code: [[legal certainty]] (non-retroactivity), the notion of "ordre public" and the forbidding of the "arrêt de règlement" which was a characteristic production of the Ancien Régime's judges and was contrary to the idea that only the law prevails.
In 1801 he was placed in charge of the Department of Religion or Public Worship, and in that capacity had the chief share in drawing up the provisions of the [[Concordat of 1801]]. In 1803 he became a member of the [[Académie française]], in 1804 [[Minister of Worship (France)|Minister of Public Worship]], and in 1805 a ''[[Legion of Honour|Chevalier Grand-Croix de la Légion d'honneur]]''. He soon after became totally blind, and, after an operation, he died at Paris.
==References== *{{EB1911|wstitle=Portalis, Jean Étienne Marie|volume=22|pages=110–111}} ''In turn, it cites as references:'' **''Oeuvres by F. Portalis'' (1823) **[[Frederick Portalis]], ''Documents, rapports, et travaux inédits sur le Code Civil'' (1844); ''Sur le Concordat'' (1845) **René Lavole, ''Portalis, sa vie et ses œvres'' (Paris, 1869)

Entrepreneur |spouse = }} '''Karel Urbánek''' (born 22 March 1941 in [[Bojkovice]], [[Moravia]]) is a retired Czech politician. He was the last [[Communism|Communist]] leader of [[Czechoslovakia]] during the [[Velvet Revolution]]. A former [[Bojkovice]] railway station manager, he replaced [[Miloš Jakeš]] as Secretary General of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia]] after a swift election on 24 November 1989. The only important decision he made during his very short term was to cancel the clause of the Constitution which gave the Communist Party a monopoly of power, though Communist rule had effectively ended with Jakeš' resignation.{{cite web|url=http://www.ustrcr.cz/cs/karel-urbanek|title=Karel Urbánek|publisher=Ústav pro studium totalitních režimů|language=Czech|accessdate=27 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101013038/http://www.ustrcr.cz/cs/karel-urbanek|archivedate=1 January 2009|df=}} He remained as party leader until 20 December, when he was succeeded by [[Ladislav Adamec]]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{First Secretaries of the KSČ}} {{Leaders of the Ruling Parties of the Eastern Bloc}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Urbanek, Karel}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bojkovice]] [[Category:Czech communists]] [[Category:Leaders of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia]] [[Category:People of the Velvet Revolution]] {{CzechRepublic-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox writer | name = Kathleen Collins | embed = | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1942|3|18}} | birth_place = [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|9|18|1942|3|18}} | death_place = United States | resting_place = | occupation = Writer, playwright, author, filmmaker, educator | language = English | residence = | nationality = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = Fiction | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Kathleen Collins''' (March 18, 1942 – September 18, 1988) (also known as Kathleen Conwell, Kathleen Conwell Collins or Kathleen Collins Prettyman) was an African-American poet, playwright, writer, filmmaker, director, civil rights activist, and educator from [[Jersey City, New Jersey]]. Her two feature narratives—''The Cruz Brothers and Miss Malloy'' (1980) and ''[[Losing Ground (1982 film)|Losing Ground]]'' (1982)—furthered the range of Black women's films. Although ''Losing Ground'' was denied large-scale exhibition, it was among the first films created by a Black woman deliberately designed to tell a story intended for popular consumption, with a feature-length narrative structure.{{cite book|last1=Bobo|first1=Jacqueline|title=black women film and video artists|date=1998|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-92041-8|pages=8–9}} Collins thus paved the way for Julie Dash's ''[[Daughters of the Dust]]'' (1991) to become the first feature-length narrative film created by a Black woman to be placed in commercial distribution. Influenced by [[Lorraine Hansberry]], she wrote about "African Americans as human subjects and not as mere '''race''' subjects" [emphasis in the original]. ==Background== Born to Loretta (''née'' Pierce) and Frank Conwell and raised in New Jersey, Kathleen, at the age of 15,
won first prize at an annual poetry reading contest at [[Rutgers University–Newark|Rutgers Newark College of Arts and Sciences]] for her rendition of [[Walt Whitman]]'s 'A Child Goes Forth' and 'I Learned My Lesson Complete'. An article in the March 3, 1958 ''[[Jersey Journal]]'' reported that in addition to working as assistant editor of the [[Lincoln High School (New Jersey)|Lincoln High School]]'s publication the ''Leader'', Conwell was on the editorial staff of the school yearbook, the ''Quill''; a member of the National Honors Society; and a past secretary of the Student Council.[http://kathleencollins.org/about/ "About"], Kathleen Collins website.
After graduating from high school in 1959, Collins went to [[Skidmore College]], where she received a BA in philosophy and religion in 1963. In 1962, after her campus was visited by two leaders of the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]] (SNCC), she became active in the [[Civil Rights Movement]], canvassing in [[Georgia (US state)|Georgia]] for black residents to register to vote; as a result, she was arrested twice while working with the [[Albany Movement]].{{cite book|last1=Andrews|first1=William L.|last2=Foster|first2=Frances Smith|last3=Harris|first3=Trudier|title=The Concise Oxford Companion to African American Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-9XtCY7cijMC&pg=PA79|accessdate=August 28, 2012|date=February 15, 2001|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-513883-2|page=79}}{{cite book|last=Carson|first=Clayborne|title=The Student Voice, 1960–1965: Periodical of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HIrMMp6_QMcC&pg=PA57|accessdate=28 August 2012|year=1960|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-88736-323-8|page=57}} After she graduated from Skidmore, she taught high-school French in [[Newton, Massachusetts]], while attending graduate school at [[Harvard]] at night. In 1965, she won a scholarship to study in France at [[Paris-Sorbonne University]], where, in 1966, she obtained an MA in French literature and cinema. ==Career== Collins joined the faculty of City College at the [[City University of New York]] and became a professor of film history and screenwriting,{{Cite news|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2016/12/01/what-happened-to-kathleen-collins/|first=Danny|last=King|title=What Happened to Kathleen Collins|work=[[The Village Voice]]|date=December 1, 2016|access-date=July 26, 2018}} where cinematographer Ronald K Gray encouraged her to go ahead with a screenplay she had adapted from a [[Henry Roth]] short story. That film became ''The Cruz Brothers and Mrs. Malloy'', which eventually won First Prize at the [[Sinking Creek Film Festival]]. This was followed in 1982 by ''[[Losing Ground (1982 film)|Losing Ground]]'' (starring Seret Scott, [[Bill Gunn (writer)|Bill Gunn]], and [[Duane Jones]]), which she wrote and directed. ''[[Losing Ground (1982 film)|Losing Ground]]'' was the first feature-length drama directed by a black American woman{{cite book | title = Post-Soul Nation: The Explosive, Contradictory, Triumphant, and Tragic 1980s as Experienced by African Americans {Previously Known as Blacks and Before That Negroes} |last = George | first = Nelson | date = 2004 | publisher = Viking | authorlink = Nelson George | isbn = 0670032751 | page = 37 }} and won First Prize at the [[Figueroa International Film Festival]] in [[Portugal]], garnering much international acclaim. Both films were shot in [[Rockland County, New York]], and are currently distributed by [[Milestone Films]].[http://www.independentcinemaoffice.org.uk/media/Films/LosingGroundPK.pdf "Losing Ground"], Milstone Film & Video. Collins wrote many other plays and screenplays, but her two most well-known theatrical plays are ''In the Midnight Hour'' (1981) and ''The Brothers'' (1982), both of which are available through [[Samuel French]]. Themes frequently explored in her work are issues of marital malaise, male dominance and impotence, freedom of expression and intellectual pursuit, and her protagonists are cited as "typically self-reflective women who move from a state of subjugation to empowerment."{{cite book|last=Nelson|first=Emmanuel Sampath|title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Multiethnic American Literature: A - C|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tWH3wNV5HpQC&pg=PA482|accessdate=August 28, 2012|year=2005|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33060-5|page=482}} ===Posthumous accomplishments=== On Collins' abrupt death in 1988, the bulk of her work, most of it unpublished, was left to her daughter, Nina Collins, who in 2006 began to sift through her mother's enormous archive and began working to have it published, restored and reissued. In 2015 ''[[A Public Space]]'' posthumously published Collins' short story "Interiors", a fictionalized account of her divorce from her first husband.{{cite web|last1=Collins|first1=Kathleen|title=Interiors|url=http://apublicspace.org/magazine/detail/interiors_collins|journal=A Public Space|issue=23|accessdate=September 5, 2016}} Collins' 1982 ''Losing Ground'' was restored and reissued in 2015.{{cite web|title=Kathleen Collins's Lost Masterwork, "Losing Ground"|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/02/09/lost-found|website=The New Yorker}} The film had its first theatrical release in 2015 at Film Society of Lincoln Center, opening the series "Tell it like it is: Black Independents in New York, 1968-1986". It would later be described in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' as "the great rediscovery of 2015".{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/whatever-happened-to-interracial-love-kathleen-collinss-revelatory-short-stories|title="Whatever Happened to Interracial Love?": Kathleen Collins's Revelatory Short Stories|last=Brody|first=Richard|date=December 1, 2016|work=The New Yorker|access-date=June 28, 2018|language=en-US}} ''Losing Ground'' and ''The Cruz Brothers and Mrs. Malloy'' were released together on two-disc sets (DVD or Blu-ray) by Milestone in April 2016. In December 2016, a collection of Collins' short stories was published under [[HarperCollins|HarperCollins']] [[Ecco Press|Ecco]] imprint under the title ''[[Whatever Happened to Interracial Love?]]'' The title story was published by ''[[Granta]]'' in July 2016.{{cite journal|last1=Collins|first1=Kathleen|title=Whatever Happened to Interracial Love?|url=https://granta.com/whatever-happened-to-interracial-love/|work=Granta|issue=136: Legacies of Love|date=July 13, 2015|accessdate=September 5, 2016}} These acclaimed{{Cite news|url=https://www.harpercollins.com/9780062484154/whatever-happened-to-interracial-love/|title=Whatever Happened to Interracial Love? - Kathleen Collins - Paperback|work=HarperCollins Publishers|access-date=July 26, 2018|language=en-US}} stories were written in the 1970s and mined some of the same intimate territory of Black women's lives, loves, and losses as ''[[Losing Ground (1982 film)|Losing Ground]].'' Prior to its release, it was listed as one of the most anticipated books of the fall of 2016 by the ''[[HuffPost|Huffington Post]], [[New York (magazine)|New York]], [[The Boston Globe]], [[Lithub|Lit Hub]],'' and ''[[The Millions]].'' The collection received starred reviews in ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' and ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' and was named one of the best books of 2016 by outlets that included ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]],'' [[NPR]]''',''' ''[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]]''''',''' ''[[Publishers Weekly]], and'' [[Vice Media|VICE]]. ==Personal life== Collins was married, but divorced in 1975.{{cite web|last1=Collins|first1=Nina|title=The Fighter: Domestic Violence Against Men|url=http://www.elle.com/life-love/sex-relationships/advice/a11650/the-fighter-562842/|work=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|date=March 24, 2013|accessdate=September 5, 2016}} She had two children from her marriage: Nina Lorez Collins and Emilio Collins. She was married a second time, to [[Alfred Prettyman]].{{cite web|title=Kathleen Collins, a Film Maker, Dies at 46|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/24/obituaries/kathleen-collins-a-film-maker-dies-at-46.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date= September 24, 1988|accessdate=September 5, 2016}} Collins died from breast cancer in 1988 at the age of 46,{{cite web|last1=Lorez Collins|first1=Nina|title=How Kathleen Collins's Daughter Kept Her Late Mother's Career Alive|url=http://www.vogue.com/13471816/kathleen-collins-filmmaker-career-daughter-nina-lorez-collins/|work=[[Vogue magazine|Vogue]]|date=September 5, 2015|accessdate= September 5, 2016}} in [[Memorial Hospital (New York City, New York)|Memorial Hospital]], New York. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://kathleencollins.org/about/ Kathleen Collins] official website. * {{imdb name|0172432}} * Ashley Clark, [http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/features/making-ground-remembering-kathleen-collins "Making ground: remembering Kathleen Collins"], ''Sight & Sound'', May 23, 2016. * Rebecca Williams, [http://bathrobeblog.blogspot.co.uk/2015/01/my-mentor-kathleen-collins-black-woman.html "My Mentor, Kathleen Collins, Black Woman Filmmaker"], Confessions of a Bathrobe Blogger, January 30, 2015. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Conwell, Kathleen}} [[Category:African-American women writers]] [[Category:African-American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:African-American screenwriters]] [[Category:Screenwriters from New York (state)]] [[Category:African-American film directors]] [[Category:African-American educators]] [[File:Billy the Kid corrected.jpg|thumb|Billy the Kid c. 1880]] The '''legend of Billy the Kid''' has acquired iconic status in American folklore, yet the outlaw himself, also known as William Bonney, had minimal impact on historical events in [[New Mexico Territory]] of the late 1800s.<ref name="Tatum1982">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=3}}</ref> More has been written about [[Billy the Kid]] than any other [[Gunfighter|gunslinger]] in the history of the American West,<ref name="MullinWelch1973">{{cite journal|author1=Robert N. Mullin|author2=Charles E. Welch, Jr.|title=Billy the Kid: The Making of a Hero|journal=Western Folklore|date=April 1973|volume=32|issue=2|page=107|doi=10.2307/1498322|jstor=1498322}}</ref> while hundreds of books, motion pictures, radio and television programs and even a ballet have been inspired by his legend.<ref name="Wishart2004">{{cite book|editor=David J. Wishart|author=Jon Tuska|title=Encyclopedia of the Great Plains|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rtRFyFO4hpEC&pg=PA446|year=2004|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-4787-7|page=446}}</ref>
When he was still alive, "Billy the Kid" had already become a nationally known figure whose exploits, real and imaginary, were reported in the [[National Police Gazette]] and the large newspapers of the eastern United States. After his death on July 14, 1881, all of New York City's papers ran his obituary, and within days, newspapers around the United States were printing exaggerated and romanticized accounts of Billy the Kid's short career.<ref name="Nolan1999">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The West of Billy the Kid|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mYhw78YF12IC&pg=PA291|date=1 September 1999|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3104-7|page=291}}</ref> In the fifteen or so [[dime novel]]s about his criminal career published between 1881 and 1906, the Kid was an outlaw antihero, customarily depicted as a badman with superior gunslinging skills, or even as a demonic agent of [[Satan]] who delighted in murder.<ref name="Tatum198245">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=45}}</ref><ref name="Anderson1999">{{cite book|author=Eric Gary Anderson|title=American Indian Literature and the Southwest: Contexts and Dispositions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EmF2CgAAQBAJ&pg=PA47|year=1999|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-70488-6|page=47}}</ref>
==Beginning of the legend== [[File:The Authentic Life of Billy, the Kid Title Page.jpg|thumb|Garrett's "The Authentic Life of Billy, the Kid" was published in 1882]] Within six weeks of Bonney's death there appeared the first complete narrative of his life, ''The True Life of Billy the Kid''. Written by dime novelist John Woodruff Lewis under the pen name "Don Jenardo", this pulp novel depicted Billy the Kid as a sadistic psychopath.<ref name="Nolan2014">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The Billy the Kid Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MwjjBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|date=20 October 2014|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8254-4|page=3}}</ref>
[[Pat Garrett]], smarting from local outrage over his shooting of the Kid,<ref name="Boggs2013">{{cite book|author=Johnny D. Boggs|title=Billy the Kid on Film, 1911-2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4SiXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA12|date=20 September 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-1-4766-0335-3|page=12}}</ref> wanted to present his side of the story and hoped to turn a profit as well on the American public's fascination with the notorious outlaw. Consequently, he published his account of Bonney's life, ''[[The Authentic Life of Billy, the Kid]]'', in 1882.<ref name="Nolan2014358">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The Billy the Kid Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MwjjBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA358|date=20 October 2014|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8254-4|page=358}}</ref> It was credited to Garrett, but the first fifteen chapters were a concoction of factual material mixed with fabrications, written by [[Roswell, New Mexico|Roswell]]'s postmaster, Ash Upson, an itinerant journalist.<ref name="Keleher2008">{{cite book|author=William A. Keleher|title=The Fabulous Frontier, 1846-1912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d-c1kDce60UC&pg=PA144%E2%80%93145|date=March 2008|publisher=Sunstone Press|isbn=978-0-86534-620-8|page=144}}</ref><ref name="Utley2000">{{cite book|author=Robert Marshall Utley|title=Billy the Kid: A Short and Violent Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h6BuOmP_VuoC&pg=PA210|year=2000|publisher=Tauris Parke Paperbacks|isbn=978-1-86064-601-0|page=210}}</ref> The remaining chapters, written in a more restrained style, are generally accurate, and were likely composed by Garrett himself.<ref name="Prassel1996">{{cite book|author=Frank Richard Prassel|title=The Great American Outlaw: A Legacy of Fact and Fiction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X9jLOv_r_asC&pg=PA153|date=1 September 1996|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-2842-9|page=153}}</ref> The book failed to find a wide audience and sold just a few copies; nevertheless, although filled with many errors of fact, ''The Authentic Life'' served afterwards as the main source for most books written about the Kid until the 1960s.<ref name="Nolan2014358" /><ref name="Tatum1982123">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|pages=123–124}}</ref><ref name="Tuska1994">{{cite book|author=Jon Tuska|title=Billy the Kid, his life and legend|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ijLXAAAAMAAJ|date=30 May 1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|page=237}}</ref> Thus was established the mythic stature of Pat Garrett as the heroic lawman in pursuit of the villainous but romantic desperado, Billy the Kid.<ref name="Tuska1994114">{{cite book|author=Jon Tuska|title=Billy the Kid, his life and legend|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ijLXAAAAMAAJ|date=30 May 1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|page=114}}</ref>
The lawman and former ranch hand [[Charlie Siringo]], who in his youth had ridden the range of eastern New Mexico and the [[Texas Panhandle]], the familiar haunts of William Bonney and Pat Garrett, and knew both of them, first told his version of the Kid's story in a chapter of his book, "A Texas Cowboy" (1885).<ref name="Tuska1994113">{{cite book|author=Jon Tuska|title=Billy the Kid, his Life and Legend|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ijLXAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Charlie%20Siringo%22|date=30 May 1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|page=113}}</ref> In 1920, he published a sympathetic biography, ''History of Billy the Kid'', in which he described the daily life of a cowboy realistically, but romanticized his account of Bonney with fantasies and exaggerations—its title page claimed "His six years of daring outlawry has never been equalled in the annals of criminal history."<ref name="Siringo1920">{{cite book|author=Charles A. Siringo|title=History of "Billy the Kid,"|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VakaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1|year=1920|publisher=C.A. Siringo|page=1}}</ref><ref name="Utley2015">{{cite book|author=Robert M. Utley|title=Wanted: The Outlaw Lives of Billy the Kid and Ned Kelly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FCLYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT108|date=17 November 2015|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-21668-4|pages=108–109}}</ref><ref name="Lamar2005">{{cite book|author=Howard Roberts Lamar|title=Charlie Siringo's West: An Interpretive Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qsr7-ThlRe0C&pg=PA88|year=2005|publisher=UNM Press|isbn=978-0-8263-3669-9|page=88}}</ref>
Three governors of New Mexico wrote accounts of their dealings with Billy the Kid.<ref name="Nolan1999299">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The West of Billy the Kid|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mYhw78YF12IC&pg=PA299|date=1 September 1999|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3104-7|page=299}}</ref> [[Miguel Antonio Otero (born 1859)|Miguel Antonio Otero]], the first governor of the territory, knew William Bonney,<ref name="Rivera2006">{{cite book|author=John-Michael Rivera|title=The Emergence of Mexican America: Recovering Stories of Mexican Peoplehood in U.S. Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C1PH1Crr4iEC&pg=PA112|date=1 May 2006|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-7558-5|page=112}}</ref> and was the first [[Mexican Americans|Mexican-American]] author to write about him. Otero's book, ''The Real Billy the Kid: With New Light on the Lincoln County War'', was published in 1936. In it, he wrote admiringly of Bonney and described events of the time and place from the perspective of native New Mexicans.<ref name="Wallis2007">{{cite book|author=Michael Wallis|title=Billy the Kid: The Endless Ride|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qViLb3BCaAAC&pg=xvi|year=2007|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-06068-3|page=xvi}}</ref><ref name="Otero2006">{{cite book|author=Miguel Antonio Otero|title=The Real Billy the Kid: With New Light on the Lincoln County War; Facsimile of Original 1936|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JloxyqgoJnkC&q=%22By%20all%20accounts%22#v=snippet&q=%22By%20all%20accounts%22&f=false|date=15 December 2006|publisher=Sunstone Press|isbn=978-1-61139-100-8|page=iii}}</ref> The Kid spoke Spanish fluently and was well-liked by the ''Hispanos'' of the [[Pecos River|Pecos River Valley]], who told many stories about ''el Chivato'', their colloquial Spanish for a young goat or kid.<ref name="Tuska1994239">{{cite book|author=Jon Tuska|title=Billy the Kid, his Life and Legend|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ijLXAAAAMAAJ&q=%22El%20Chivato%22|date=30 May 1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|page=239}}</ref><ref name="Fackler2003">{{cite book|author=Elizabeth Fackler|title=Billy the Kid: The Legend of El Chivato|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Jv1QuY_ZbIC&pg=PA512|year=2003|publisher=Sunstone Press|isbn=978-0-86534-401-3|page=512}}</ref><ref name="Adler1951">{{cite journal|author=Alfred Adler|title=Billy the Kid: A Case Study in Epic Origins|journal=Western Folklore|date=April 1951|volume=10|issue=2|doi=10.2307/1497967|jstor=1497967|publisher=Western States Folklore Society|page=144}}</ref>
===Emerging symbol of the Old West=== The modern legend of Billy the Kid as an immortal figure of the Old West first developed within a larger cultural context of social upheaval in the late 19th and early 20th century United States.<ref name="Reid2004">{{cite book|author=Margaret K. Reid|title=Cultural Secrets as Narrative Form: Storytelling in Nineteenth-century America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4FCmNOeyyJoC&pg=PA151|year=2004|publisher=Ohio State University Press|isbn=978-0-8142-0947-9|page=151}}</ref> Between 1897 and 1909, during the [[Progressive era]] of political activism and reform, the popular American novelist [[Emerson Hough]] wrote magazine articles, novels and informal histories that reintroduced Billy the Kid to a national audience, albeit in works that often relied more on fantasy than on actual events.<ref name="Utley2015109">{{cite book|author=Robert M. Utley|title=Wanted: The Outlaw Lives of Billy the Kid and Ned Kelly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FCLYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT109|date=17 November 2015|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-21668-4|page=109}}</ref><ref name="Tatum198249">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=49}}</ref> Hough embellished the Kid's reputation with lurid descriptions of his exceptional villainy in an article called "Billy the Kid: The True Story of a Western 'Bad Man' ", written in 1901 for the literary publication, ''[[Everybody's Magazine]]'', using language like "the soul of some fierce and far-off carnivor got into the body of this little man, this boy, this fiend in tight boots and a broad hat."<ref name="Tatum198256">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ&q=%22carnivore%22|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=56}}</ref><ref name="Hough1901">{{cite magazine |last =Hough |first =Emerson|date=September 1901|title = Billy the Kid: The True Story of a Western 'Bad Man' |url = https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=mdp.39015023579140;view=1up;seq=316 | magazine = Everybody's Magazine |publisher = The Ridgeway Company | location = New York | accessdate = August 30, 2016}}</ref> Hough further developed this image of the Kid in his book about western desperados, ''The Story of the Outlaw'' (1907), though not in such excessive language.<ref name="Dworkin2015">{{cite book|author=Mark J. Dworkin|title=American Mythmaker: Walter Noble Burns and the Legends of Billy the Kid, Wyatt Earp, and Joaquín Murrieta|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YFbZBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA38|date=27 February 2015|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-4902-8|page=38}}</ref><ref name="Hough1907">{{cite book|author=Emerson Hough|title=The Story of the Outlaw: A Study of the Western Desperado|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qxI7AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA273|year=1907|publisher=Grosset & Dunlap|pages=273–274}}</ref>
By the mid-1920s, however, Bonney's place in the general awareness of the American public had diminished to the point that in 1925 Harvey Fergusson asked in the ''[[American Mercury]]'' magazine, "Who remembers Billy the Kid?".<ref name="Nolan2015">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The West of Billy the Kid|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LdazBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA295|date=16 February 2015|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-4887-8|page=295}}</ref> His reputation was revitalized the next year when Walter Noble Burns's book, ''The Saga of Billy the Kid'', appeared as the Book-of-the-Month Club selection for December 1926, and became a bestseller.<ref name="Fishwick1975">{{cite book|author=Marshall William Fishwick|title=American Heroes: Myth and Reality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lrsqAAAAYAAJ&q=%E2%80%9CBonney%22|year=1975|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-8371-6610-0|page=94}}</ref> This success, and the fact that people who had actually known William Bonney were beginning to talk to reporters and write their memoirs, allowed stories of his exploits to regain a nationwide audience.<ref name="Tatum1982101">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|pages=101–102}}</ref> Publication of "The Saga", in spite of its dubious facts and fabricated events, subsequently led to a proliferation of other books, magazines and newspaper articles, and then movies, about the life of Billy the Kid.<ref name="Nolan2014104">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The Billy the Kid Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MwjjBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA104|date=20 October 2014|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8254-4|page=104}}</ref>
Depictions of Billy the Kid in popular culture fluctuated between the poles of cold-blooded murderer without a heart and sentimental hero fighting for justice.<ref name="Reid2004" /> Kent Ladd Steckmesser wrote: "There are two Billy the Kids in legend. The first is a tough little thug, a coward, a thief, and a cold-blooded murderer. The second is a romantic and sentimental hero, the brave and likeable leader of an outnumbered band fighting for justice."<ref name="Woods1990">{{cite book|author=Gregory Woods|title=Articulate Flesh: Male Homo-eroticism and Modern Poetry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2JPRuVNMwloC&pg=PA240|date=7 February 1990|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-04752-3|page=240}}</ref> Both facets of his legend were perpetuated in often poorly researched biographies, as well as in fictionalized [[B movie]]s, many of which were nonetheless commercially successful.<ref name="Tatum1982193">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|pages=193–194}}</ref>
The dramatic aspects of William Bonney's short life and violent death still appealed to popular taste, as they had in the heyday of the dime novels, but eventually an idealized image of Billy the Kid, as one who defends the underdog and fights against social injustice, came to the fore.<ref name="Tatum1982190">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=190}}</ref> The Texas historian, [[J. Frank Dobie]], wrote in ''A Vaquero of the Brush Country'' (1929): "...because his daring apotheosized youth—youth in the saddle—youth with a flaming gun—and because his daring kept him running and balancing on the edge of a frightful precipice...Billy the Kid will always be interesting, will always appeal to the popular imagination."<ref name="DobieYoung1998">{{cite book|author1=J. Frank Dobie|author2=John D. Young|title=A Vaquero of the Brush Country: The Life and Times of John D. Young|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NA3RtIWYWhEC&pg=PA169|date=1 August 1998|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-78704-9|page=169}}</ref>
===Billy the Kid in film and on stage=== With the publication in 1926 of [[Walter Noble Burns]]'s book,"The Saga of Billy the Kid", the Kid's legend revived and was consolidated as a standard tale of the American Old West.<ref name="LeemingPage1999">{{cite book|author1=David Leeming|author2=Jake Page|title=Myths, Legends, and Folktales of America: An Anthology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VNaftfbYp3gC&pg=PA147|date=28 January 1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-972895-4|pages=147–148}}</ref> The American movie director [[King Vidor]], who had wanted to film a Western-themed movie for some time, was inspired when he read Burns's book, and felt that the Kid's story had considerable dramatic appeal.<ref name="Boggs201327">{{cite book|author=Johnny D. Boggs|title=Billy the Kid on Film, 1911-2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4SiXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA27|date=20 September 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-1-4766-0335-3|pages=27–30}}</ref> Following the commercial success of the first movie he directed for the [[Metro Goldwyn Mayer]] studio, ''[[The Big Parade]]'' (1925),<ref name="DurgnatSimmon1988">{{cite book|author1=Raymond Durgnat|author2=Scott Simmon|title=King Vidor, American|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VpR7J8Qd6z0C&pg=PA59|date=January 1988|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-05798-2|page=59}}</ref> he was able to obtain backing for a Billy the Kid production when [[Irving Thalberg]], an executive at MGM, took an interest in his proposal. ''[[Billy the Kid (1930 film)|Billy the Kid]]'', the first [[sound film|talking picture]] version of the legend, was released in 1930.<ref name="DurgnatSimmon198896">{{cite book|author1=Raymond Durgnat|author2=Scott Simmon|title=King Vidor, American|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VpR7J8Qd6z0C&pg=PA96|date=January 1988|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-05798-2|page=96}}</ref> The film featured former college football star [[Johnny Mack Brown]] in the title role and Hollywood character actor [[Wallace Beery]] as Pat Garrett, but it was a box office failure. Nevertheless, Vidor's ''Billy the Kid'' set the pattern for Billy the Kid movies for the next fifty years, as other [[Filmmaking|filmmakers]] followed its formula and made the Kid an instrument of justified vengeance and his enemies the villains of the story.<ref name="Wallis2007"/><ref name="Utley2015107">{{cite book|author=Robert M. Utley|title=Wanted: The Outlaw Lives of Billy the Kid and Ned Kelly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FCLYCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT107|date=17 November 2015|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-21668-4|page=107}}</ref><ref name="Herzberg2013">{{cite book|author=Bob Herzberg|title=Hang 'Em High: Law and Disorder in Western Films and Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KSJ5AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA13|date=28 August 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-6838-6|page=13}}</ref>
As Billy the Kid was reborn a romantic or tragic figure in literature and films of the 1920s–1940s;<ref name="Johnson2007">{{cite book|author=Michael L. Johnson|title=Hunger for the Wild: America's Obsession with the Untamed West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZkQUAAAAYAAJ&q=%22tragic%20figure%22|year=2007|publisher=University Press of Kansas|isbn=978-0-7006-1501-8|page=172}}</ref> [[high culture]] began to turn its attention to his legend in the late 1930s. [[Lincoln Kirstein]], co-founder with [[George Balanchine]] of the [[School of American Ballet]], drew material from Burns' book to write the libretto for a ballet to be called ''[[Billy the Kid (ballet)|Billy the Kid]]'', performed by his new group, the ''Ballet Caravan''.<ref name="Siegel1979">{{cite book|author=Marcia B. Siegel|title=The Shapes of Change: Images of American Dance|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EGePMESpK10C&pg=PA118|year=1979|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04212-4|page=118}}</ref> Composer [[Aaron Copland]] was commissioned to score the music, and [[Eugene Loring]] to do the choreography.<ref name="Levy2012">{{cite book|author=Beth E. Levy|title=Frontier Figures: American Music and the Mythology of the American West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LwHN2K8bpAEC&pg=PA323|date=18 April 2012|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-95202-7|page=323}}</ref> The ballet premiered at the [[Chicago Civic Opera House]] on October 16, 1938, and has since become a repertory standard.<ref name="Smith2011">{{cite book|author=Helen Smith|title=There's a Place for Us: The Musical Theatre Works of Leonard Bernstein|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sgIiD92NnwQC&pg=PA8|year=2011|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-1169-7|page=8}}</ref><ref name="Krokover1956">{{cite book|author=Rosalyn Krokover|title=The new Borzoi book of ballets|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H1A5AAAAIAAJ&q=%22October%2016,%201938%22|year=1956|publisher=Knopf|page=44}}</ref> Copland arranged the score for a concert suite that was performed and recorded in 1959 by [[Leonard Bernstein]] conducting the [[New York Philharmonic Orchestra]]; the recording was released by Columbia Records in 1960.<ref name="North2006">{{cite book|author=James H. North|title=New York Philharmonic: The Authorized Recordings, 1917-2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t0ayG9YhQAQC&pg=PA117|date=15 June 2006|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6239-5|page=117}}</ref>
''The Outlaw'', starring [[Jack Buetel]] as Billy the Kid, [[Walter Huston]] as [[Doc Holliday]], and [[Jane Russell]] in her first movie role, was produced by [[Howard Hughes]] and finished in 1941, though not released until 1943. The film, directed for the most part by [[Howard Hawks]] (Hughes got the screen credit), was promoted in a publicity campaign with posters featuring Russell posing in dishabille and her cleavage prominently displayed.<ref name="McDonald2011">{{cite book|author=William McDonald|title=The Obits: The New York Times Annual 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MZtSJX1sTq0C&pg=PA323|date=11 November 2011|publisher=Workman Publishing Company|isbn=978-0-7611-6942-0|page=323}}</ref><ref name="HallNeale2010">{{cite book|author1=Sheldon Hall|author2=Stephen Neale|title=Epics, Spectacles, and Blockbusters: A Hollywood History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jhvrSwOOsRgC&pg=PA131|year=2010|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=0-8143-3008-8|page=131}}</ref> Its emphasis on Jane Russell's physical attributes led to the film being dubbed the first "sex western".<ref name="Lang2002">{{cite book|author=Robert Lang|title=Masculine Interests: Homoerotics in Hollywood Films|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y-U7kxhDklYC&pg=PA80+p.+80%E2%80%9381|year=2002|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-11300-7|pages=80–81}}</ref><ref name="Gehring1999">{{cite book|author=Wes D. Gehring|title=Parody as Film Genre: "never Give a Saga an Even Break"|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MGI2vdGPN6UC&pg=PA112|year=1999|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-26186-2|page=112}}</ref> Although the movie was generally panned by movie critics,<ref name="McDonald2011" /> it was rereleased twice over the course of the next decade, grossing more than $20 million<ref name="Gevinson1997">{{cite book|author=Alan Gevinson|title=Within Our Gates: Ethnicity in American Feature Films, 1911-1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bsoUXGZSxZcC&pg=PA751+|year=1997|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-20964-0|page=751}}</ref> and solidifying the legend of Billy the Kid (although a distorted and unhistorical one) in the consciousness of the American filmgoing public.<ref name="DurgnatSimmon198883">{{cite book|author1=Raymond Durgnat|author2=Scott Simmon|title=King Vidor, American|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VpR7J8Qd6z0C&pg=PA83|date=January 1988|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-05798-2|page=83}}</ref>
The film director [[Sam Peckinpah]] attempted an ambitious retelling of the legend in his last western film,<ref name="Seydor2015">{{cite book|author=Paul Seydor|title=The Authentic Death and Contentious Afterlife of Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid: The Untold Story of Peckinpah's Last Western Film|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HjTVBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT11|date=15 February 2015|publisher=Northwestern University Press|isbn=978-0-8101-6820-6|page=11}}</ref> ''[[Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid]]'' (1973), covering the last few months of Bonney's life,<ref name="Simmons2004">{{cite book|author=Garner Simmons|title=Peckinpah|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sPFstxHbWDQC&pg=PA170|date=1 July 2004|publisher=Hal Leonard|isbn=978-1-61774-449-5|page=170}}</ref> in which the violence and physical brutality of the world the protagonists inhabited is portrayed realistically.<ref name="Dukore1999">{{cite book|author=Bernard Frank Dukore|title=Sam Peckinpah's Feature Films|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NjLdMBBPQUcC&pg=PA177|year=1999|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-06802-7|page=177}}</ref> The film suffered from production difficulties as well as from Peckinpah's battles with MGM over his artistic vision and budget overruns. The studio's drastically cut release version, disowned by Peckinpah, was initially a failure with major critics and the viewing public. Although its depiction of the Kid as a roguish anarchist opposed to illegitimate law (as enforced by Garrett on behalf of a corrupt power structure) was suited to the temper of the times,<ref name="Nolan2014363">{{cite book|author=Frederick Nolan|title=The Billy the Kid Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MwjjBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA363|date=20 October 2014|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-8254-4|page=363}}</ref> it quickly left first-run theaters. Soon, however, reviews began to appear in smaller film magazines and journals in the United States and abroad that praised its artistry and breadth of vision. The film's reputation was on the ascendancy long before Peckinpah's preferred cut of the preview version was finally shown at the University of Southern California in 1986,<ref name="Boggs2013209">{{cite book|author=Johnny D. Boggs|title=Billy the Kid on Film, 1911-2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4SiXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA209|date=20 September 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-1-4766-0335-3|page=209}}</ref> and its critical stature has continued to increase since—[[Martin Scorsese]], e.g., called it a "masterpiece". Despite the liberties it took with history, scholar and film editor Paul Seydor<ref name="Seydor1999">{{cite book|author=Paul Seydor|title=Peckinpah: The Western Films, a Reconsideration|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jamhwSywQCEC&pg=PA411|year=1999|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-06835-5|page=411}}</ref> described ''Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid'' as among the finest treatments of the legend in any medium.<ref name="Seydor201516">{{cite book|author=Paul Seydor|title=The Authentic Death and Contentious Afterlife of Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid: The Untold Story of Peckinpah's Last Western Film|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HjTVBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT16|date=15 February 2015|publisher=Northwestern University Press|isbn=978-0-8101-6820-6|page=16}}</ref>
==Billy the Kid as cultural icon== The psychoanalyst [[Alfred Adler]] wrote an analysis in 1951 of the mythic aspects of the legend of Billy the Kid in which he compared the Kid to [[Oedipus]], [[King Arthur]], [[Robin Hood]], and other legendary heroes of the past.<ref name="Adler1951" /> Adler was the first writer to discuss the symbolic significance of Billy the Kid's nickname as a cultural totem.<ref name="Fackler2003"/>
[[Arthur Penn]]'s film, ''[[The Left Handed Gun]]'' (1958), portrays Billy the Kid as a misunderstood youth, played by Paul Newman in the manner of [[James Dean]] in ''[[Rebel Without a Cause]]'', according to the film critic Robert Kolker. It similarly addresses the psychological motivations of those of its characters who resort to violence,<ref name="Kolker2011">{{cite book|author=Robert Phillip Kolker|title=A Cinema of Loneliness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LJlJjCEk_UYC&pg=PA45|date=7 July 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-973888-5|page=45}}</ref> in a pseudo-[[Freud]]ian treatment of the subject characteristic of certain 1950s movies.<ref name="Herzberg2013134">{{cite book|author=Bob Herzberg|title=Hang 'Em High: Law and Disorder in Western Films and Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KSJ5AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA134|date=28 August 2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-6838-6|page=134}}</ref>
In 1941 Life magazine ran a piece on Billy the Kid called ''America's Best-Loved Badman''.<ref name="Murdoch2001">{{cite book|author=David Hamilton Murdoch|title=The American West: The Invention of a Myth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3dFIhTAVvNQC&pg=PA98|year=2001|publisher=University of Nevada Press|isbn=978-0-87417-369-7|page=98}}</ref> The historian Stephen Tatum, writing forty years later, referred to the contradictory aspects of the mythical Billy the Kid, calling him a "flexible container" into which audiences poured their "hopes and fears, ideals and prejudices."<ref name="Tatum198211">{{cite book|author=Stephen Tatum|title=Inventing Billy the Kid: Visions of the Outlaw in America, 1881-1981|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4jWAAAAMAAJ&q=%22flexible%20container%22|date=1 January 1982|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-0610-4|page=11|quote=If the legend reveals contradictory features, the reason is because the Kid has been since his death in 1881 many things to many people—a flexible container, in other words, into which particular audiences' hopes and fears, ideals and prejudices, have been poured.}}</ref> Writers and filmmakers have often depicted William Bonney as the personification of the "free-running reprobate" of the Old West, of the sort whom the reformed outlaw [[Emmett Dalton]] wondered if "he symbolizes the undying anarchy in the heart of every man."<ref name="Dalton2011">{{cite book|author=Emmett Dalton|title=When the Daltons Rode|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yt2ZBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT178|date=31 October 2011|publisher=Pelican Publishing Company|isbn=978-1-4556-1536-0|page=178}}</ref> In any case, the mythical Billy the Kid remains an icon of popular American culture,<ref name="Wallis2007"/> and the skinny, bucktoothed kid from New York City occupies the top place in Western American folklore.<ref name="Brunvand2006">{{cite book|author=Jan Harold Brunvand|title=American Folklore: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OY-OAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA164|date=24 May 2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-57878-7|pages=164–165}}</ref><ref name="Heller2004">{{cite book|author=Arno Heller|editor=Walter Hölbling, Arno Heller|title=What is American?: New Identities in U.S. Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YQyHAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA259|year=2004|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-8258-7734-7|chapter=Reinventing Billy the Kid: The Juvenile Delinquent as Icon|pages=259–260}}</ref> The mythologizing continues with new works in various media.<ref name="FeeWebb2016">{{cite book|editor=Christopher R. Fee, Jeffrey B. Webb|title=American Myths, Legends, and Tall Tales: An Encyclopedia of American Folklore (3 Volumes)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kXnEDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA145|date=31 August 2016|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-61069-568-8|pages=145–146}}</ref><ref name="Slatta2001">{{cite book|author=Richard W. Slatta|title=The Mythical West: An Encyclopedia of Legend, Lore, and Popular Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iczSBcAUC5oC&pg=PA47|year=2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-151-9|page=47}}</ref>

revision.text: {{short description|16th/17th-century English Hispanist and poet}} '''Leonard Digges''' ({{IPAc-en|d|ɪ|g|z}}; 1588 – 7 April 1635) was an accomplished [[Hispanist]] and minor poet,{{DNB Cite|wstitle=Digges, Leonard (1588-1635)}}S.H. Steinberg, "Digges, Leonard," in: ''Cassell's Encyclopedia of World Literature,'' New York: Funk & Wagnalls, 1953. a younger son of the astronomer [[Thomas Digges]] (1545–95, and younger brother of Sir [[Dudley Digges]] (1583–1639). After his father's death in 1595, his mother married Thomas Russell of Alderminster,A village about four miles south of Stratford. who was named by [[William Shakespeare]] as one of the two overseers of his will. There are varying opinions about the extent to which the young Leonard Digges might have been influenced in his choice of profession by his stepfather's association with Shakespeare; disagreements about whether he was or was not personally acquainted with the playwright have in recent years eclipsed discussion of the work of Digges himself. ==Life== Leonard Digges matriculated at [[University College, Oxford]] in 1603, the year of his mother's remarriage, and graduated BA in 1606. This was followed by a period of study abroad. He may have traveled to Spain with fellow Hispanist [[James Mabbe]], whom he knew from Oxford, for he wrote a note on the flyleaf of a book which Mabbe sent from Madrid to Will Baker, also a friend from Oxford days. The book was a copy of ''Rimas'' by [[Lope de Vega]] (published in 1613); it still survives, in the library of [[Balliol College]]. Digges's inscription reads: ::Will Baker: Knowinge ::that Mr Mab: was to ::sende you this Booke ::of sonets, wch with Spaniards ::here is accounted of their ::lope de Vega as in Englande ::wee sholde of or: Will ::Shakespeare. I colde not ::but insert thus much to ::you, that if you like ::him not, you muste neuer ::neuer reade Spanishe Poet :::::Leo:DiggesPaul Morgan, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ws1SAlRJ-Y8C&pg=PA118&lpg=PA118#v=onepage&q&f=false "'Our Will Shakespeare' and Lope de Vega: An Unrecorded Contemporary Document,"] in Allardyce Nicoll (ed.),''Shakespeare Survey,'' 16,Cambridge University Press, 2002 reprint, pp.118-120: Samuel Schoenbaum, ''William Shakespeare: a compact documentary life,'' ibid.p.313 [[Anthony Wood (antiquary)|Anthony a Wood]] said of Leonard Digges that he "was esteemed by those who knew him in Univ.coll. a great master of the English language, a perfect understander of the French and Spanish, a good poet, and no mean orator."Wood, Anthony, [https://archive.org/stream/athenaeoxoniense02wooduoft/athenaeoxoniense02wooduoft_djvu.txt ''Athenae Oxonienses: an Exact History of all the Writers and Bishops who have had their Education in the University of Oxford from 1500 to 1690''], published in London in 1692. Wood says also that "upon his supplication made to the venerable convocation" of University College Oxford, Digges was made M.A. in 1626, "in consideration that he had spent many years in good letters in transmarine universities." He lived in the College from then until his death in 1635, and was buried in the College chapel (no longer standing). ==Works== Digges translated [[Claudian]]'s ''The Rape of Proserpine'' (printed [[1617 in literature|1617]]). His translation of ''Varia fortuna de soldado Píndaro'' by [[Gonzalo de Céspedes y Meneses]], was published in [[1622 in literature|1622]] as ''Gerardo, the Unfortunate Spaniard'', and was used by [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] as a source for his plays ''[[The Spanish Curate]]'' and ''[[The Maid in the Mill]]''. Digges's publisher was [[Edward Blount]], a close friend of Mabbe's and one of the syndicate which published Shakespeare's [[First Folio]] in 1623. Digges and Mabbe both contributed prefatory poems to the Folio, as did [[Ben Jonson]]—also published by Blount. The previous year, Digges and Jonson had both contributed [[commendatory verse]]s to a work translated by Mabbe and published by Blount.Freehafer, John, "Leonard Digges, Ben Johnson, and the Beginning of Shakespeare Idolatry", ''Shakespeare Quarterly'', Vol. 21, No. 1 (Winter, 1970), pp. 63-75 Commendatory verses by Digges were also included in an edition of Shakespeare's ''Poems'', published by [[John Benson (publisher)|John Benson]] in 1640, five years after Digges had died. Freehafer suggests that since these verses refer to Shakespeare's plays rather than to his poems, they may have been intended for the Second Folio. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://library.leeds.ac.uk/special-collections/view/578/first_folio_home,0 First Folio Digital Resource] - Leeds University Library {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Digges, Leonard}} [[Category:1588 births]] [[Category:1635 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century English poets]] [[Category:17th-century male writers]] [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:People associated with Shakespeare]] [[Category:Spanish–English translators]] [[Category:British Hispanists]] [[Category:English male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:English male poets]]

{{Expand list|date=February 2011}} [[File:KhomyakovA AvtoportretABR.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Aleksey Stepanovich Khomyakov, co-founder of the Slavophile movement]] This is a '''list of 19th-century Russian [[Slavophile]]s''':
'''Slavophilia''' is an intellectual movement originating from the 19th century that wanted the [[Russian Empire]] to be developed upon values and institutions derived from its early history. Slavophiles were especially opposed to the influences of Western Europe in Russia.<ref name=Brit>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9068172/Slavophile Encyclopædia Britannica Slavophile article]</ref> There were also similar movements in Poland, Hungary and Greece.
== Prominent Slavophiles == *'''[[Ivan Aksakov|Ivan Sergeyevich Aksakov]]''' (Russian: Иван Сергеевич Аксаков; {{OldStyleDate|October 8|1823|September 26}} - {{OldStyleDate|February 8|1886|January 27}}, [[Moscow]]) was a [[Russia]]n [[littérateur]] and notable Slavophile. He was the son of [[Sergey Aksakov]] and brother to [[Vera Aksakova]] and [[Konstantin Aksakov]]. He was born in what is now [[Bashkortostan]]. *'''[[Konstantin Aksakov|Konstantin Sergeyevich Aksakov]]''' ({{lang-ru|Константин Серге́евич Аксаков}}) (1817–1860) was a [[Russia]]n critic and writer, one of the earliest and most notable Slavophiles. He wrote plays, social criticism, and histories of the ancient Russian social order.<ref name="Russell Bova">Russia and Western Civilization: Cultural and Historical Encounters By Russell Bova</ref> His father [[Sergey Aksakov]] and sister [[Vera Aksakova]] were writers, and his younger brother [[Ivan Aksakov]] was a journalist. *'''[[Aleksey Khomyakov|Aleksey Stepanovich Khomyakov]]''' (''Алексей Степанович Хомяков'') (May 1, 1804, [[Moscow]] – September 23/25, 1860) was a [[Russia]]n religious poet who co-founded the Slavophile movement along with [[Ivan Kireevsky]], and became one of its most distinguished theoreticians. *'''[[Ivan Kireyevsky|Ivan Vasilyevich Kireyevsky]]''' ({{lang-ru|Ива́н Васи́льевич Кире́евский}}; 3 April 1806, [[Moscow]] — 23 June 1856) was a [[Russians|Russian]] literary critic and philosopher who, together with [[Aleksey Khomyakov]], co-founded the Slavophile movement. *'''[[Mikhail Pogodin|Mikhail Petrovich Pogodin]]''' ({{lang-ru|Михаил Петрович Погодин}}, 1800, [[Moscow]] - 1875) was a [[Russia]]n historian and journalist who dominated the national historiography between the death of [[Nikolay Karamzin]] in 1826 and the rise of [[Sergey Solovyov]] in the 1850s. He is best remembered as a staunch proponent of the [[Normanist theory]] of Russian statehood. In 1841 Pogodin joined his old friend [[Stepan Shevyrev]] in editing ''Moskovityanin'', a periodical which came to voice the Slavophile opinions. In the course of the following fifteen years of editing, Pogodin and Shevyrev steadily slid towards the most reactionary form of Slavophilism. *'''[[Yuri Samarin]]''' (Юрий Фёдорович Самарин; 1819-1876) was a leading Russian Slavophile thinker and one of the architects of the [[Emancipation reform of 1861]]. *'''[[Fyodor Tyutchev|Fyodor Ivanovich Tyutchev]]''' (Russian: Фёдор Ива́нович Тю́тчев; {{OldStyleDate|December 5|1803|November 23}} - {{OldStyleDate|July 27|1873|July 15}}) is generally considered the last of three great Romantic poets of Russia, following [[Alexander Pushkin]] and [[Mikhail Lermontov]]. Politically, he was a militant Slavophile, who never needed a particular reason to berate the Western powers, [[Holy See|Vatican]], [[Ottoman Empire]], or [[Poland]], perceived by him as Judas of pan-Slavic interests. The failure of the [[Crimean War]] made him look critically at the Russian government. *'''[[Nikolay Yazykov|Nikolay Mikhailovich Yazykov]]''' ({{lang-ru|Никола́й Миха́йлович Язы́ков}}, March 4, 1803, [[Simbirsk]] - December 26, 1846, [[Moscow]]) was a Russian poet and Slavophile who in the 1820s rivalled [[Alexander Pushkin]] and [[Yevgeny Baratynsky]] as the most popular poet of his generation.
== Prominent Russian nationalist and conservative thinkers influenced by Slavophile ideology ==
*[[Nikolay Yakovlevich Danilevsky|Nikolay Danilevsky]]<ref>Eduard I. Kolcjinsky, "Nikolaj Jakovlevich Danilevsky", in ''[[Encyclopedia of Anthropology]]'' ed. [[H. James Birx]] (2006, SAGE Publications; {{ISBN|0-7619-3029-9}})</ref> *[[Fyodor Dostoevsky]] *[[Ivan Ilyin]] *[[Mikhail Katkov]] *Vadim Kozhinov *[[Konstantin Leontiev]] *[[Natalia Narochnitskaya]] *[[Konstantin Pobedonostsev]] *[[Igor Shafarevich]] *[[Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)]] <ref>History of Russian Philosophy «История российской Философии »(1951), pp. 81-134.</ref> *[[Sergey Solovyov]] *[[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]] *[[Nikolay Strakhov]] *[[Lev Tikhomirov]] *[[Sergei Nikolaevich Trubetskoy|Sergei Trubetskoy]]

{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|His Excellency]] |name = Mohamed Salama Badi
محمد سلامة بادي |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |alt = |caption = |order = |office = Sahrawi Ambassador to East Timor |term_start = August 2010 |term_end = |primeminister = [[Abdelkader Taleb Omar]] |predecessor = [[Mohamed Kamal Fadel]] |successor = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1966 |birth_place = [[El Aaiun]], [[Spanish Sahara]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = [[Dili]], {{TLS}} |ethnicity = Sahrawi |citizenship = |other_names = |education = |alma_mater = University of [[Sétif]], [[Algeria]] |employer = |occupation = [[Diplomat]] |years_active = |height = |weight = |religion = [[Sunni Islam]] |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |awards = |website = |footnotes = |party = [[POLISARIO]] |box_width = }} {{Politics of SADR}} '''Mohamed Salama Badi''' (born 1966 in El Aaiun, [[Western Sahara]]) is the current [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawi]] [[ambassador]] to [[Timor-Leste]]. He speaks [[Hassaniya]] ([[Varieties of Arabic|a variety of Arabic]]), and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. == Personal life == He was an [[activist]] and [[syndicalist]] in Moroccan-occupied Western Sahara during his youth. He graduated in [[Economics]] at [[Sétif]] university, in [[Algeria]]. He then moved to [[Spain]] to complete his education, earning a [[master degree|master's degree]] in "Conflicts, Peace and Development" at [[James I University]] in [[Castellón de la Plana|Castellon]]{{cite web|title= Máster en Estudios Internacionales de Paz, Conflictos y Desarrollo - Antiguos alumnos|url=http://www.epd.uji.es/web/es/master_antiguos_estudiantes.html|publisher=Cátedra UNESCO de Filosofía para la Paz - Universitat Jaume I|accessdate=03-11-2011|language=es}} and a [[doctorate]] at the [[University of Granada]].{{cite news|title=Presidente reafirma apoio ao Saara Ocidental|url=http://www.portalangop.co.ao/motix/pt_pt/noticias/internacional/2010/5/23/Presidente-reafirma-apoio-Saara-Ocidental,0d88eae5-4e0f-48c4-80f7-223bf55b4706.html|publisher=[[ANGOP]]|date=07-06-2010|accessdate=2012-10-14|language=pt}} == Diplomatic postings == He started his diplomatic career during the 1990s, as the head of the [[Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]] general delegation in [[Syria]]. Then, in the late 2000s, he joined the [[Pan-African Parliament]] in representation of his country.http://www.pan-african-parliament.org/Controls/Documents.aspx?DID=1062{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Pan-African Parliament Committee on Monetary and Financial Affairs Finally, in 2010 he replaced [[Mohamed Kamal Fadel]] as ambassador of the SADR to Timor-Leste[http://www.presidencia.tl/09%20PPR%20EmbSADR_EN.checked.DOC President of the Republic confirms Timor-Leste's support during the presentation of credentials of the ambassador of Western Sahara]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Presidência da República – Press release. ==Honours and awards== On May 16, 2012, Salama Badi was awarded with the [[Order of Timor-Leste]] by [[President of East Timor]] [[José Ramos-Horta]].{{cite news|title=President of East Timor grants Order of Merit to Saharawi ambassador|url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/president-east-timor-grants-order-merit-saharawi-ambassador|publisher=[[Sahara Press Service]]|date=2012-05-17|accessdate=2012-05-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120914045104/http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/president-east-timor-grants-order-merit-saharawi-ambassador|archivedate=2012-09-14|df=}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left;" |-- ! colspan=2 width="490px" | Award or decoration ! width="110px" | Country ! width="110px" | Date ! width="110px" | Place ! width="500px" | Note ! Ref |- | width="80px" | [[File:Order of Timor-Leste.png|80px]] | style="font-size:90%;"|[[Order of Timor-Leste|Medal of the Order of Timor-Leste]] | style="width:8em; font-size:90%;"|{{flag|East Timor}} | align="center" style="width:10em; font-size:90%;"|16 May 2012 | align="center" style="font-size:90%;"|[[Dili]] | style="font-size:90%;"|East Timorese highest honour. | style="font-size:90%;"|{{cite news|title=Accredited ambassadors in Dili receive Order of Timor-Leste medals|url=http://presidenttimorleste.tl/?p=5450|publisher=The Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste - Office of the President|date=2012-05-16|accessdate=2012-11-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126042239/http://presidenttimorleste.tl/?p=5450|archivedate=2013-11-26|df=}} |- |} == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Badi, Mohamed Salama}} [[Category:Polisario Front politicians]] [[Category:Sahrawi Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic to East Timor]] [[Category:Sahrawi activists]] [[Category:Syndicalists]] [[Category:University of Granada alumni]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic to Syria]] [[Category:Members of the Pan-African Parliament from the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Timor-Leste]]
