{{Infobox person | name = Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva | image = Sangarren.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva | birth_date = 30 August 1841 | birth_place = [[Bayonne]], France | death_date = {{death-date and age|1 April 1906|30 August 1841|}} | death_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = war | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Aragon]]ese | citizenship = spanish | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = landowner | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = Carlism | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva, 1st Count of Altarriba, 24th Baron of Sangarrén''' (30 August 1841 – 1 April 1906), was an Aragonese-Catalan [[Carlist]] politician and soldier.
==Family and youth== [[File:Bergara - Real Seminario 1.JPG|thumbnail|left|Bergara, former Seminario Cientifico]] Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva was born into a distinguished aristocratic [[Aragon]]ese family of Altarriba, from Catalan origin, possibly from the old distinguished Catalan noble family of [[Altarriba]] in [[Catalonia]], which was part of the [[Crown of Aragon]] at the time, holding [[baron]]ia de Sangarrén since the 14th century<ref>Porfirio Sanz Camañes, ''Del Reino a la Corte. Oligarquías y élites de poder en las Cortes de Aragón a mediados del siglo XVII'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia Moderna. Anales de la Universidad de Alicante'' 19 (2001), pp. 39, 43, 83, also ''Sangarrén, baronia de'' entry [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa'' online, available [http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=11401 here]</ref> and [[count|condado]] de Robres since the 18th century;<ref>''Robres, Conde de'' entry at ''compactgen'' service, available [http://compactgen.com/es/r/rob.htm here]</ref> its representatives were many times noted in the history of Aragón and [[Zaragoza]].<ref>Santiago Broto Aparicio, ''Nobleza altoaragonesa: Condes de Robres'', [in:] ''Diario del Alto Aragón'' online, available [http://www.diariodelaltoaragon.com/NoticiasImprimir.aspx?Id=549630 here]</ref> His paternal grandmother, María Bernarda Colón Sierra,<ref>she married Ramón’s paternal grandfather, José Jacobo Altarriba y Calasanz; José Ramón Urquijo Goitia, María Jesús Álvarez-Coca González, ''José Joaquín Colón y la rehabilitación de la monarquía absoluta'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia Jerónimo Zurita'' 87 (2012), p. 176</ref> was descendant of [[Christopher Columbus]].<ref>Urquijo, Álvarez-Coca 2012, pp. 172-173; for detailed genealogical tree see ''genealogiacolombiana'' service available [http://www.genealogiacolombiana.com/doc/6%20desc/6.1.6.1.pdf here] and look for the "José Altarriba y Calasanz" box</ref> Ramón’s father, [[José de Altarriba y Colón de Larreátegui]] (1804-1870), 11th [[:es:Condado de Robres|conde de Robres]]<ref>''Robres, Conde de'' entry at ''compactgen'' service</ref> and 22nd [[baronia de Sangarrén|barón de Sangarrén]], was a Carlist highly esteemed by [[Infante Carlos, Count of Montemolin|Carlos VI]]; no details of his involvement in the movement are available.<ref>Francisco de Paula, ''Album de Personajes Carlistas con sus Biografias'', volume II, Barcelona 1888, p. 171, Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 180</ref> Ramón’s mother, also from Aragón, María Pilar Villanueva y Altarriba (1820-1895), was daughter of [[:es:Condado de Atarés|conde de Atarés]] and second cousin of his father José.<ref>see the ''Heirs of Europe'' service available [http://heirsofeurope.blogspot.com/2010/02/atrisco.html here]</ref>
None of the sources consulted clarifies why the family lived in the French [[Bayonne]], a usual location for Carlist exiles and refugees fleeing Spain in the aftermath of defeat suffered during the [[First Carlist War]]. Ramón was one of 8 siblings and the second oldest son.<ref>see ''geneallnet'' service available [http://geneall.net/es/name/514649/jose-de-altarriba-y-colon-de-larreategui/ here], entry nr 67</ref> His older brother, [[José María Altarriba y Villanueva|José María]], upon return to Aragón followed the family path and also engaged in Carlist activities,<ref>e.g. he was the co-founder, together with conde de Fuentes, Bienvenido Comín y Sarté and José Puente y Villabueva, of the Carlist ''La Esperanza'' daily, Julio V. Brioso y Mairal, ''Noticias carlistas en "El Diario de Huesca"'', [in:] Fernando Alvira Banzo (ed.), ''El Diario de Huesca. 125 años después'', Huesca 2000, {{ISBN|8481271101}}, pp. 74-75</ref> which did not prevent him from becoming [[comisario regio]] for Zaragoza in 1869;<ref>and a Carlist candidate to the Cortes from Sariñena in 1871, Brioso 2000, p. 74</ref> he inherited all family titles in 1870. Ramón as a youngster moved from France to Spain and entered [[Real Seminario Científico Industrial]],<ref>María Cinta Caballer Vivies, ''Los alumnos de la Escuela Especial de Matemáticas del Real Seminario Científico Industrial de Vergara'', [in:] Revista de la Sociedad Española de Historia de las Ciencias y de las Técnicas'' 32 (2009), p. 260</ref> a state-ran and highly esteemed<ref>only 22% of the alumni were from Vascongadas; 55% originated from the rest of Spain and 23% from abroad, including America, Caballer 2009, p. 282</ref> [[Gipuzkoa]]n educational establishment in [[Bergara]].<ref>Caballer 2009, p. 260</ref> He is reported as enrolled in 1854, though it is not clear when he completed the curriculum; the standard cycle lasted 5 years.<ref>Caballer 2009, p. 228; it is not clear what development path Ramón’s parents envisaged; the school, apart from training commercial merchants, was a stepping stone towards military career (usually in artillery) or provided general training enabling its student to run family estates, Caballer 2009, p. 260</ref>
Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva married Rosa Guerra y Serbi; nothing is known of this marriage, apart that his wife died in 1875 and the couple had no issue.<ref>see ''Altarriba'' and ''conde de Altarriba'' entries at ''compactgen'' service, available [http://www.compactgen.com/cg/a/l/altarr.htm here]</ref> He then espoused María de la Blanca Porcel y Guirior (1859-1940),<ref>see ''Villa Alegre'' entry at ''compactgen'' service, available [http://compactgen.com/es/v/vil.htm here]; some sources spell her family name as "Guirioz", see Luisa Utanda Moreno, Francesco Feo Parrondo, ''Propiedad rustica en Guipuzcoa segun el registro de la propiedad expropiable (1933)'', [in:] ''Lurralde. Investigación y espacio'' 18 (1995), pp. 113-135, available [http://www.ingeba.org/lurralde/lurranet/lur18/utanda18/18utanda.htm here], or „Guerior", see Miguel Caballero Pérez, Pilar Góngora Ayala, ''Historia de una familia: la verdad sobre el asesinato de García Lorca'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|8495803593}}, 9788495803597, p. 149</ref> heir to aristocratic family originating from Gipuzkoa and [[Andalusia]]. Since her father<ref>Luciano Porcel Valdivia, marqués de Villa Alegra y de San Millán, native of Beasáin, represented Gipuzkoa in the Senate in 1871, Caballero 2007, p. 149</ref> died in 1873<ref>''Villa Alegre'' entry at ''compactgen''</ref> with no male descendants, having been the oldest daughter she arranged to inherit his titles as 7th [[:es:Marquesado de Villa Alegre de Castilla|marquesa de Villa Alegre]] and [[marquesado de San Millán|San Millán]]; Altarriba became marqués consorte.<ref>their descandants were not entitled to the honor, ''Villa Alegre'' entry at ''compactgen''</ref> The couple had two sons, [[Ramón Altarriba y Porcel|Ramón]] and [[Jaime Altarriba y Porcel]].<ref>see ''Ramón de Altarriba y Villanueva'' entry at ''geneallnet'' service, available [http://geneall.net/es/name/515805/ramon-de-altarriba-y-villanueva-1-conde-de-altarriba-24-baron-de-sangarren/ here]</ref> Nothing is known about the former; the latter (1884–1936)<ref>see ''Jaime Altarriba y Porcel'' entry at ''compactgen'' service, available [http://compactgen.com/getperson.php?personID=I1144&tree=tree1 here]; at his baptism the padrinos were the future Carlist king Don Jaime and his sister doña Blanca, see ''La Unión'' 07.05.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004873708&page=3 here]</ref> joined artillery and pursued a military career.<ref>see ''ABC'' 14.09.10, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1910/09/14/016.html here]</ref> He became comandante de Artilleria, maestrante de la [[:es:Real Maestranza de Caballería de Zaragoza|Real Maestranza de la Caballeria de Zaragoza]]<ref>he followed in the foosteps of his father, see de Paula 1888, p. 173; see also ''Real Maestranza de Caballeria de Zaragoza'' website available [http://www.rmcz.com/ here]</ref> and an entrepreneur.<ref>see ''Askar'', [in:] ''Zumaiako Industria-ondarearen Informazio Zentroa'' web bulletin 2012, available [http://www.ziiz.eus/es/motorgintza/talleres-askar/ here]</ref> Also an active Carlist, in 1934 he headed finance section of [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]].<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, 9780521086349, p. 207</ref> The [[Spanish coup of July 1936|1936 coup]] surprised him in the Gipuzkoan spa of [[Zestoa]], where he was detained by the republican militia and died.<ref>according to a Basque source he died due to tuberculosis, see ''Askar''; a different version presented in the Carlist publication, Félix G. Olmedo, ''En España empieza a amanecer: a la memoria de Jaime Altarriba Porcel'', s/l 1936. In the same Zestoa spa the Republicans detained also a Carlist activist and a former MP, Joaquín Beunza, who was later taken to San Sebastián and executed, see ''Joaquín Beunza Redin'' entry [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/13724 here]</ref>
==War and war== [[File:Fortuny Soldat marroquí.jpg|thumbnail|150px|left|Moroccan soldier 1860]] Upon the outbreak of [[Hispano-Moroccan War (1859–60)|Primera Guerra de Marruecos]] in 1859 the young Altarriba volunteered to the army; accepted, he was assigned to the Aragon infantry unit of [[Regimento de Zamora]] and landed in [[Ceuta]] in December 1859.<ref>Nicolas Estevanez, ''Mis memorias'', Madrid 1975, {{ISBN|8472730883}}, pp. 49</ref> Details of his service are unclear, though he certainly entered many combat actions against the Moroccan troops. Serving under the command of [[Antonio Ros de Olano]]<ref>Estevanez 1975, p. 8</ref> in January 1860 he might have taken part in the [[battle of Castillejos]]; bypassing Monte Negrón in a dare Spanish maneuver,<ref>Estevanez 1975, pp. 54-55</ref> he then participated in the [[battle of Cabo Negro]].<ref>Estevanez 1975, p. 55</ref> For meritorious service Altarriba was awarded [[Laureate Cross of Saint Ferdinand|Cruz de San Fernando]]<ref>''Ramón Altarriba y Villanueva'' entry [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/19966 here]</ref> and got promoted to [[teniente]].<ref>de Paula 1888, pp. 171–2; ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' claims he was promoted to capitán</ref> Late 1860 the unit returned to the Zaragoza barracks.<ref>Estevanez 1975, p. 69</ref> Apparently enjoying adventurous life and vivacious company, he demonstrated some gift for rhyming couplets;<ref>compare "Y cuaitdo al castillo vuelven / mis caballos arrogantes, / les doy a comer diamantes / en morrales de tisú", or "Queridisimo rechoncho, / debes pedir una plancha / para quitar esa mancha / que te ha caído en el poncho", quoted after Estevanez 1975, p. 70.</ref> at that time he befriended [[:es:Nicolás Estévanez Murphy|Nicolas Estevanez Murphy]].<ref>Estevanez 1975, p. 69</ref> During the next few years Altarriba continued his military career, though no details are known. [[File:Barón de Sangarren.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Barón de Sangarren]] Following the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|Revolution of 1868]] Altarriba requested and was granted release from military service,<ref>his service in the Isabelline army was later called against him by some Carlists, see Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 180</ref> though he returned to the army in 1871.<ref>''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> Once the [[First Spanish Republic|Republic]] was declared he approached the conspiring Carlists<ref>''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''; in 1871 his brother was a Carlist candidate to the Cortes from Sariñena, Brioso 2000, p. 74</ref> and at the outbreak of the [[Third Carlist War]] he was already incorporated in their army.<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 172, ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> He was assigned to the Northern front and took command of an insurgent volunteer [[Biscay]] battalion, which conquered and cleared the [[Durango (Spain)|Durango]] district in 1873.<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 172</ref> Promoted to [[Colonel|coronel]], he then commanded primera brigada de Vizcaya and joined the siege of [[Bilbao]] in early 1874; he led the unit routing the Republican forces during the [[:es:Valle de Somorrostro|battle of Somorrostro]]<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 172</ref> and advancing later to [[Portugalete]],<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 172</ref> where Altarriba was given the privilege of accepting surrender of the famous [[battalón de Segorbe]].<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 172</ref> Participated in a number of skirmishes at the outskirts of Bilbao, assaulting the forts of Delmas and Volantín.<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 173</ref> Nominated Comandante General del Alto Aragón, Altarriba was the organizer, sponsor and commander of [[Battalón de Almogávares de la Virgen del Pilar]],<ref>Ampelio Alonso de Cadenas y Lopez (ed.), ''Suplemento al Elenco de grandezas y títulos nobiliarios españoles: Títulos vacantes y títulos extranjeros cuyo uso fue autorizado en España. Appendice II'', Madrid 1991, {{ISBN|8487204295}}, 9788487204296, p. 11</ref> leading it early 1875 during the defense of the so-called [[línea de Carrascal]]<ref>de Paula 1888, p. 173</ref> and in the [[Navarre]]se battles of [[Lumbier]] and [[Etxauri]].<ref>''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> In final phase of the war and in unclear circumstances there was an investigative proceeding launched against Altarriba; eventually cleared of all charges, he was promoted to [[brigadier]].<ref>de Paula 1888, pp. 173-4</ref> Located in mid-range command chain, he did not make it amongst top Carlist commanders and did not supervise operations above the tactical level. Nominated adjutant to [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]],<ref>''ABC'' 01.04.06, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1906/04/01/010.html here], de Paula 1888, p. 174</ref> in reward for his service Altarriba was conceded the title of [[condado de Altarriba|conde de Altarriba]].<ref>Cadenas 1991, p. 11. Unlike many other aristocratic titles awarded by Carlist claimants, often recognised by Franco in the 1950s and functional until today, condado de Altarriba has never been confirmed. It is not clear whether any of Altarriba’s descendants claims the title currently</ref>
==Early ''Restauración''== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] A widower with no close family, it is not clear where Altarriba settled after the war; in 1877 he was linked to the [[Catalonia|Catalan]] town of [[Avià|Aviá]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.04.77, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000020835&page=1 here]</ref> In 1878 he was already married<ref>at that time he was already reported by the press as marqués de Villalegre, see ''La Unión'' 12.09.78, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003886463&page=3 here]</ref> and assumed administration of his wife’s property in Gipuzkoa. The estates slightly exceeding 1,000 ha<ref>the estate did not make an impressive figure by national Spanish standards; as late as in 1919 duque de Peñaranda possessed 51,000 ha, Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''Aristocracia y poder económico en la España del siglo XX'', [in:] ''Vegueta'' 7 (2003), p. 157; in the sole Cordoba district there were around 30 landholders with estates exceeding 1,000 ha, see [http://www.magrama.gob.es/ministerio/pags/Biblioteca/fondo/pdf/14761_2_4.pdf here], p. 80-81 [surface area is listed in fanegas (fgs), a fanega differed from province to province, though one scholar suggests an average of 1 fg = 1,044 ha for the nearby Almeria province, see [http://www.dipalme.org/Servicios/Anexos/anexosiea.nsf/VAnexos/IEA-BN1_c4/$File/BN1-c4.pdf here], p. 88]</ref> rendered the couple the 4th largest [[Landowners|terratenientes]] in the province<ref>most of the holdings, some 400 ha, was in the district of Azpeitia, see Moreno, Parrondo 1995</ref> and one of the richest people in Gipuzkoa.<ref>Javier Real Cuesta, ''El Carlismo Vasco 1876-1900'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|978-84-323-0510-8}}, p. 28</ref> His wife held land also in [[Álava]] and Andalusia;<ref>Brioso 2000, p. 74, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 98</ref> for some time Altarriba managed the [[Pinos Puente]] estate in [[Granada (province)|Granada]], which she possessed jointly with her two unmarried sisters, though with rather mediocre result.<ref>Caballero, Góngora 2007, pp. 149-150</ref> In 1878 José María Altarriba, unmarried and with no issue,<ref>see ''José María de Altarriba y Villanueva'' entry at ''geneallnet'' service, available [http://geneall.net/es/name/515804/jose-maria-de-altarriba-y-villanueva/ here]</ref> renounced baronia<ref>but not condado de Robres</ref> in favor of his younger brother, making Ramón the 24th barón de Sangarrén.<ref>see ''La Unión'' 12.09.78, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003886463&page=3 here], ''La Epoca'' 19.11.78, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000378574&page=4 here]</ref>
Altarriba seemed pessimistic as to the future of Carlism,<ref>he deemed it necessary that "se modifique la tactica de hacerle hacer el muerto [al partido], porque el simil y la realidad solo se separan ya en esto por un atomo impalable", quoted after Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 1-2</ref> considered orphaned, with no political direction<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 7</ref> and managed by ineffective Junta Militar.<ref>Altarriba was not nominated its member, Real Cuesta 1985, p. 2</ref> In 1878 he wrote to Carlos VII urging him to appoint a strong political leader.<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 8</ref> As in early 1879 the military rule was terminated and civic rights restored in Gipuzkoa,<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 41</ref> Altarriba – already admitted to a meeting of leading Carlists – spoke in favor of taking part in the [[Spanish general election, 1879|elections]].<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 6</ref> The claimant allowed only individual unofficial contenders and authorized Sangarrén.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 59, Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 15, 41</ref> Fielding his candidature in the [[Azpeitia]] district,<ref>most of Altarriba’s estates were in Azpeitia district</ref> Altarriba was considered one of the 4 "transigentes" running;<ref>some Carlists, firmly opposed to new laws scrapping most of the fuerista establishments and called "intransigentes", ran on the Union Vasconavarra platform, though with no success</ref> he emerged as the only one victorious.<ref>the defeated ones were Olano Altuna, Pedro de Egańa (Gipuzkoa) and Domingo Martinez de Aragón (Alava), Real Cuesta 1985, p. 42. Altarriba became the only Carlist deputy in the chamber and the first Carlist MP of the [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration era]].</ref> Elected,<ref>see official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%284410%29.NDIP. here]</ref> he settled permanently in [[Madrid]].<ref>initially he was listed as living at calle San Leonardo (university quarter), see ''Anuario del Comercio'' 1881, p. 425, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004967953&page=425 here], than at calle Alarcon (Jeronimos quarter), see ''Anuario del Comercio'' 1894, p. 563, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005143535&page=563 here], and finally at Pza Independencia, see ''Anuario del Comercio'' 1905, p. 68, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005330970&page=68 here]</ref> He attempted [[Spanish general election, 1881|re-election in 1881]]<ref>issuing a manifesto mocked by the liberal press as "mas expresivo y pintoresco en su clase", Altarriba himself dubbed as "Don Quijote" see ''El Globo'' 09.08.81, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001125141&page=1 here], full text in ''La Iberia'' 06.08.81, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001504379&page=1 here]; according to one source this manifesto caused official investigation and Altarriba narrowly avoided trial, de Paula 1888, p. 174</ref> but lost both in [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]] and Azpeitia.<ref>''La Discussion'' 22.08.81, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002471418&page=2 here], also ''El Globo'' 22.08.81, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001125461&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Cabecilla 1884.JPG|thumbnail|160px|guerra periodistica]] The 1880s are marked by growing rivalry within Carlism, divided between the immovilistas and the aperturistas. The former, led by [[:es:Candido Nocedal|Candido Nocedal]], opted for intransigence. The latter, Altarriba included, dismissed either war<ref>despite crushing defeat in 1876, in the 1880s the Carlists still maintained some military potential; it was estimated that within 3 days they were able to mobilise 4,000–6,000 people, and skeleton battalion structures were still maintained with commanders, officers and NCOs appointed, Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 83–84</ref> or total abstention, preferring conditional alignment with the new political system. The dispute grew into a full-scale conflict, waged also by means of guerra periodistica;<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 24, see ''El Cabecilla'' 09.03.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003844914&page=3 here]</ref> to fight the Nocedalista titles,<ref>principally ''El Siglo Futuro'', Real Cuesta 1985, p. 28</ref> Sangarrén founded a Madrid satirical weekly, ''[[El Cabecilla]]''.<ref>issued in 1882-1890 and directed by Gonzalez Granada, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 98</ref> During the [[Spanish general election, 1884|1884 election]] campaign Altarriba sought Carlos VII’s exemption from "despotism" of Nocedal, who ordered abstention, but this time the claimant did not agree<ref>''Revista Contemporanea'' 3–4 1884, p. 360, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002409566&page=360 here]</ref> and Sangarrén loyally<ref>in 1886 Altarriba confessed that he accepted the tyranny of Candido Nocedal only because the latter was appointed by the king, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 81</ref> withdrew from the race 3 weeks prior to election date.<ref>as usual he intended to run in Azpeitia, see ''El Liberal'' 09.03.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001117859&page=2 here]</ref> Two years later, already a recognized Carlist leader,<ref>in 1886 he took part in unveiling of the Cegama monument to Zumalacarregui, financed mostly by public subscription, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 94</ref> he obtained the permission<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 97-8</ref> and was [[Spanish general election, 1886|re-elected]] from Azpeitia.<ref>see official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%284410%29.NDIP. here]</ref> Focused on by the press as a single Carlist in the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]],<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 98</ref> when sworn Altarriba declared in the house that he considered Carlos VII the king of Spain.<ref>de Paula 1888, pp. 174-177; though fiercely anti-democratic, Altarriba was member of a parliamentary anti-slavery group, see ''La Ilustriación Católica'' 25.04.89, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003175111&page=11 here]</ref>
As the Nocedalista crisis entered its terminal phase, in 1887 Altarriba engaged in a related conflict with [[Francisco Cavero y Alvarez de Toledo]], the jefe of Aragón,<ref>Cavery tried to rebuke Donostia gatherings organized by Altarriba, see ''[[La Ilustración Española y Americana]]'' 08.09.1887, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001125969&page=2 here], and disenfranchised Círculo Aragonés, inspired by Sangarrén and considered his frondist outpost in Aragon</ref> with Carlos VII intervening and ordering truce;<ref>the claimant called Cavero to his Venice residence and ordered end of public polemics, though Cavero kept rising in the Carlist structures later on, see Ignacio Martínez de Pisón, ''Carreteras secundarias'', Zaragoza 2012, {{ISBN|8415538685}}, 9788415538684, p. IX, also ''Cavero y Álvarez de Toledo, Francisco'' entry [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa'' online, available [http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=3487 here]</ref> some authors claim that Cavero was dismissed.<ref>and present the Altarriba – Cavero conflict in a slightly different way, see Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Carlins i integristes a la Restaurado: Tescissió de 1888'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 147 (1991), p. 63</ref> Though assaulted by the Nocedalista press for his defense of [[Manifesto de Morentin]],<ref>Canal 1991, p. 63</ref> in the unfolding press war Altarriba defended the vacillating ''[[La Fe (Spanish daily)|La Fe]]'' and did not side unconditionally with the claimant; Carlos VII’s entourage counted him among "malos Carlistas".<ref>Canal 1991, p. 66</ref> Somewhat accidentally triggering the final breakup in [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]],<ref>during one of his Cortes addresses Altarriba compared some governmental measures to "la Inquisición con todos sus tormentos". The pro-Integrist Biscay periodical ''El Vasco'' jumped on this phrase, denouncing Altarriba as anti-Catholic and anti-Traditionalist. The Vascongadas Carlist leader, marqués de Valde-Espina, ordered ''El Vasco'' to backtrack, but the Biscay provinvial jefe, José de Accilona, took an independent stand, which resulted in provincial schism taking place in 1887, followed by the Gipuzkoan one in 1888, Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 93–97</ref> at the decisive moment he stayed loyal to his king.
==Personal political climax== [[File:Altarriba y Villanueva.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|Altarriba in his 50s]] Following secession of the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integristas]] Altarriba, the only party MP and one of its few aristocrats, found himself in top strata of Carlism and became one if its most distinguished politicians.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 103</ref> His relations with other party leaders were uneasy, even after departure of the allegedly hated Nocedal. The undisputed [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] leader in Vascongadas<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, p. 68–69</ref> [[:es:Juan Nepomuceno de Orbe y Mariaca|marqués de Valde-Espina]],<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 118</ref> the claimant’s personal secretary [[conde de Melgar]]<ref>fractious Carlists, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 230</ref> and the aspiring political leader, [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marqués de Cerralbo]]<ref>see Altarriba mocking Cerralbo, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 118</ref> found it difficult to work with Sangarrén and did not spare him harsh words; in the intrigue-ridden world of Carlism of the late 19th century he was accused of envy towards legitimate party leaders<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 117</ref> and turning Gipuzkoa into his personal fiefdom.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 118</ref> When in late 1888 he was appointed vice-president of the newly established Junta Directiva del Circulo Tradicionalista de Madrid,<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 118</ref> he refused the post claiming – probably sarcastically – that he did not merit such an honor.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 118, 180, also ''El Siglo Futuro'' 19.12.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000129043&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Marqués de Cerralbo, en Nuevo Mundo.jpg|thumbnail|160px|marqués de Cerralbo]] In 1889 Carlos VII started to build formal nationwide party structures, initially disguised as an organization to stage celebrations of [[:es:Conversión de Recaredo|Conversión de Recaredo]] centenary; within its Junta Central, soon turned into a permanent collegial executive,<ref>Vascongadas were represented by Valde-Espina, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 146, Real Cuesta 1985, p. 134</ref> Sangarrén was nominated to represent [[Castilla la Vieja]].<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El XVII Marqués de Cerralbo (1845–1922). Iglesia y carlismo, distintas formas de ver el XIII Centenario de la Unidad Católica'', [in:] ''Studium: Revista de humanidades'' 18 (2012) [referred to further on as "Fernández Escudero 2012 (2)"], p. 131, Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 145–46</ref> Like 10 years earlier, he called for a new jefe which would impose the party discipline, though it is not clear whether he himself hoped for the job.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 115</ref> In the fall of that year liberal press speculated about a directorate leading the movement and mentioned him one of its 4 members.<ref>along de Cerralbo, Cavero and Menendez de Luarca, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 172</ref> Altarriba’s position was confirmed when he was invited to [[Schloss Frohsdorf|Frohsdorf]] for the wedding of [[Infanta Blanca of Spain|Carlos VII’s daughter]].<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 173</ref> Though in early 1890 ''El Cabecilla'' mocked marqués de Cerralbo,<ref>causing irritation of Carlos VII, annoyed with what he considered „dirty tricks" of ''El Cabecilla'', Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 180</ref> when later that year the latter was finally appointed the new Jefe Delegado Sangarrén rushed with congratulations, directed to "mi querido amigo".<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 180</ref>
Ahead of the [[Spanish general election, 1891|1891 elections]] for the first time during Restoration the Carlists decided to take part officially and set up a co-ordinating committee. Details of its work are not known; the outcome was that in Azpeitia, which turned into a prestigious battlefield against the rebellious [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]], Sangarrén had to give way to the aspiring Gipuzkoan leader, [[Tirso Olazábal Lardizábal|Tírso de Olazábal]]. Himself he ran in two districts, [[Aranda de Duero]] ([[Burgos province|Burgos]]) and [[Santo Domingo de la Calzada]] ([[Logroño (province)|Logroño]]),<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 237–38</ref> losing in both.<ref>For Logroño see ''La Unión Católica'' 02.02.91, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004885740&page=2 here], for Aranda see ''El Imparcial'' 03.02.91, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000680556&page=2 here]</ref> Following this defeat, he did not renew his electoral bid in any of the successive electoral campaigns.<ref>Altarriba is not listed among candidates running after 1891 either by historical studies or by contemporary press, though no source consulted explicitly states that Sangarrén did not run after that date</ref>
==Mid-''Restauración''== [[File:Palacio Sangarren Usurbil.jpg|thumbnail|left|Sangarrén residence, Gipuzkoa]] Having lost the parliamentary ticket Sangarrén could dedicate more time to his private business, geographically scattered from Vascongadas across [[Castile (historical region)|Castille]] and on to Andalusia. Apart from managing family estates in Gipuzkoa, he invested in mining and metalworking industry.<ref>''Ideas y negocios. Carlistas en Moralzarzal'', [in:] ''Historias de Moral (y Zarzal)'' 01.05.12, available [http://historiasdemoralzarzal.blogspot.com/2012/05/ideales-y-negocios-carlistas-en.html here]</ref> He co-owned exploration rights to a copper mine in the [[Sierra de Guadarrama]] location of [[Colmenarejo]], North of Madrid.<ref>the pit was named "Pilar" after his wife, ''Ideas y negocios'' 2012</ref> In 1893 he took control over the "La Fe" mineral springs in the nearby [[Moralzarzal]],<ref>the previous owner was also a Carlist, Ramón Manrique de Lara, ''Ideas y negocios'' 2012</ref> renaming the site "[[:es:Mudarra|Mudarra]]" and exploiting it until 1900, when he renounced the concession.<ref>''Ideas y negocios'' 2012</ref> He held stakes in paper mill business in Pyrenaic parts of the [[Lérida Province|Lérida province]]<ref>''Madrid cientifico'' 418 (1903), p. 14, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001757766&page=14&search=sangarren&lang=es%20http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001757766&page=14 here]</ref> and was vice-president of Derecha del Rio Genil, a Granada-based company engaged in irrigation works.<ref>''La Ilustracion Española y Americana'' 22.10.79, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001102670&page=15 here]</ref>
As the Carlist [[Fuero|fuerista]] principles envisaged that a politician should only represent the region where he lives,<ref>Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 242-3</ref> within the party command structures Altarriba formally headed Castilla la Vieja.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 285</ref> Though due to his terrateniente status he exercised largest influence in Gipuzkoa,<ref>Altarriba's prestigious standing in the province was reflected in his role in a number of initiatives, like opening of the Zumarraga-Zumaya railway line, known as "ferrocaril del Urola", see [http://www.spanishrailway.com/2012/05/06/ferrocarril-del-urola-zumarraga-a-zumaya/ spanishrailway.com site]</ref> Vascongadas was first headed by Valde-Espina, then by Salvador Elío y Ezpeleta<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 285–86</ref> and later by [[Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal|Tirso de Olazábal]].<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 443</ref> Altarriba’s contribution to Gipuzkoan Carlism, however, remained crucial; local landowners were key to mobilising rural support<ref>for a sample how Sangarrén instructed "his" renters to vote see Real Cuesta 1985, p. 251</ref> and maintaining – if not straightforwardly financing – provincial party structures.<ref>though according to the fuerista outlook electoral work was to be entrusted to locals, in fact there were many exceptions, with some juntas were simply appointing nominees for different roles, triggering complaints; also Sangerrén used to complain to Valde-Espina, though in general Gipuzkoa adhered to the fuersita principles much closer than the neighboring Biscay, see Real Cuesta 1985, pp. 242–43</ref> Partially as a result of his contribution, in the 1880s and 1890s Gipuzkoa emerged as a Carlist stronghold; in provincial<ref>the number of Traditionalist (mainstream Carlism and Integrism combined) v. Liberal members elected to Diputación Provincial was: 1882 8:8; 1884 10:6; 1886 11:5; 1888 9:11; 1890 9:11; 1892 11:9; 1894 11:9; 1898 9:11, Real Cuesta 1985, p. 167</ref> and general<ref>the number of Traditionalist (mainstream Carlism and Integrism combined) v. Liberal members elected to the Cortes from Gipzukoa was: 1891 2:3; 1895 3:2; 1896 3:2; 1899 3:2, Real Cuesta 1985, p. 168</ref> elections the party was striving for domination. [[File:Don carlos de borbón nypl.jpg|thumbnail|160px|Carlos VII]] In the early 1890s fellow Traditionalists approached Altarriba cautiously as one of "fractious Carlists".<ref>"Carlistas discolos", Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 230</ref> Some sources report him as championing a militant "de armas tomar" group, consisting mostly of the Navarros and the Gipuzkoanos.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 115</ref> Other episodes seem to counter this thesis indicating that he worked closely with the non-belligerent de Cerralbo,<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, pp. 192, 199</ref> together travelling across Spain during innovative political tours and delivering harangues,<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 223, Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Banderas blancas, boinas rojas: una historia política del carlismo'', 1876–1939, Madrid 2006, {{ISBN|8496467341}}, 978849646734 , pp. 151-156</ref> also jointly with Carlist pundits like [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Vazquez de Mella]];<ref>like it was the case in 1893, see Cristobal Robles Muñoz, ''La Santa Sede y la oposición carlista a la restauración durante los episcopados de José Oliver y Antonio Ruiz-Cabal (1875-1899)'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 421</ref> residing in Madrid he customarily appeared in events staged in the capital.<ref>e.g. during the first Fiesta de los Mártires de la Tradición, see Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 293 or during other events, see Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 313</ref> As the [[Spanish–American War|colonial crisis of 1897]] unfolded, he initially seemed leaning towards a bold action; he welcomed general [[Valeriano Weyler, 1st Duke of Rubí|Weyler]], dismissed from [[Cuba]], amongst the crowd shouting "Viva Cuba Española", but also a somewhat more ambiguous "a caballo mi general".<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 338</ref> However, during the [[Spanish–American War]] Sangarrén was busy denouncing widely circulating rumors about another Carlist insurgency forthcoming as "a fable",<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 387. The government was alarmed by Guardia Civil discovering large Carlist depots of rifles and by increased traffic of Carlist envoys to Carlos VII’s residence in Venice, reported by the Spanish diplomatic service, see Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 387</ref> though it is not clear whether it was a pre-agreed propaganda smoke-screen or a genuine effort. During [[La Octubrada (Carlist uprising of 1900)|La Octubrada]], the series of minor Carlist revolts of October 1900,<ref>on 28-30 of October 1900 a series of minor and very minor Carlist attempts to seize power locally was recorded in Badalona, Casteldefells, Santa Coloma de Gramanet, Igualada, Sardañola, Alcoy, Berga, Calella, Mantesa and Moncada, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 387</ref> he was in [[Paris]],<ref>present day scholar interprets the presence of Carlist leaders in Paris as a demonstration, aimed at the Madrid government and intending to prove that they were not involved in any conspiration, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 389</ref> which did not spare him detention by [[Guardia Civil]] the following month in Bilbao.<ref>''Ideas y negocios 2012'', also ''El Dia'' 09.11.00, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002427342&page=3 here]</ref> Also during persistent rumors of mid-1902<ref>contemporary scholar suggests they were caused by speculators willing to affect the Madrid stock-exchange quotations, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 409</ref> Altarriba spoke publicly against a Carlist military action.<ref>Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 411; though some newspapers were hysterical about another Carlist war behind the corner, the other titles considered Carlism already "a cadaver", see ''La Epoca'' 20.06.02, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000680946&page=1 here]</ref> The press reported him as an agreed Carlist candidate in the [[Spanish general election, 1903|1903 elections]],<ref>''La Correspondencia militar'' 30.01.03, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001884261&page=3 here]</ref> but he was not mentioned as running later on. None of the sources consulted mentions him politically active after that date; obituaries claimed he had been suffering from an unidentified longtime "enfermedad crónica";<ref>''ABC'' 01.04.06, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1906/04/01/010.html here]</ref> his funeral was attended by the then Carlist political leader, [[Matías Barrio y Mier]].<ref>''El Globo'' 03.04.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001277034&page=2 here]</ref>

[[File:Osservatorio del Collegio Romano.jpg|thumb|Observatory of the Collegio Romano in 1852. Number 4 indicates the part of the building that accommodated a [[telescope]] by Cauchoix.]]
'''Robert-Aglaé Cauchoix''' (24 April 1776 – 5 February 1845) was a [[France|French]] [[Scientific equipment optician|optician]] and [[Scientific instrument|instrument maker]], whose [[Lens (optics)|lenses]] played a part in the race of the [[great refractor]] telescopes in the first half of the 19th century.
==Instruments== At first Cauchoix produced a wide range of scientific instruments including [[barometer]]s and [[micrometer]]s, but he soon specialized in optics, making [[spherometer]]s and [[Objective (optics)|objectives]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rauantiques.com/library/Artists%20and%20Makers/robert-aglae-cauchoix-CAUCHOIX.html | title=Robert-Aglae Cauchoix | publisher=[http://www.rauantiques.com/ M. S. Rau Antiques] | accessdate=27 February 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222145148/http://www.rauantiques.com/library/Artists%20and%20Makers/robert-aglae-cauchoix-CAUCHOIX.html | archivedate=22 February 2014 | df= }}</ref> He made a [[telescope]] for the [[Paris Observatory]] in 1820 and in 1825 he made a 6.5 inch (16.5 cm) [[refractor]] for the observatory of the [[Pontifical Gregorian University|Collegio Romano]], a [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] academy in [[Rome]]. In the [[Royal Observatory, Greenwich]] an 1838 instrument named the Sheepshanks telescope includes an objective by Cauchoix.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://collections.rmg.co.uk/collections/objects/11074.html| title=Sheepshanks telescope | publisher=[[Royal Museums Greenwich]] | location=UK | accessdate=27 February 2014 }}</ref>
==Great refractors== Although the [[reflector telescope]] was invented in the second half of the 18th century, technological difficulties made the refractor the telescope of choice until the mid-1850s.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} Improvements in lens production, like the introduction of the [[achromatic lens]] by [[John Dollond]], spawned an [[aperture]] size race that started in the early 1820s with a telescope made by the [[Germany|German]] optician [[Joseph von Fraunhofer]]. Cauchoix must be credited holding the lens size record three times this period. In 1831, Cauchoix made a 13.3 inch (almost 33.8 cm) refractor for the [[Ireland|Irishman]] [[Edward Joshua Cooper]], who used it to observe [[Halley's Comet]] in 1835 and a [[solar eclipse]] in 1836.<ref name="Abrahams">{{cite web| url=http://home.europa.com/~telscope/tsfrance.txt | title=Cauchoix biography | first=Peter | last=Abrahams | publisher=[[Antique Telescope Society]] | accessdate=27 February 2014 }}</ref>
In 1829, Cauchoix made an 11.75 inch lens for a French customer, but sold it to the British [[astronomer]] [[James South]].<ref name="Abrahams" /> South used it for his new telescope, which he found defective due to problems with the [[Telescope mount|equatorial mount]]. In 1838, this telescope was dismantled, but the lens by Cauchoix served in other instruments until 1989.
==See also== * [[List of astronomical instrument makers]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ssplprints.com/image.php?imgref=10419025 Picture of Edward Cooper's telescope], [[London Science Museum]].

'''Rupert William Simon Allason''' (born 8 November 1951) is a former [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] politician in the [[United Kingdom]] and professional author. He was the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Torbay (UK Parliament constituency)|Torbay]] in [[Devon]], from [[United Kingdom general election, 1987|1987]] to [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]]. He writes books and articles on the subject of [[espionage]] under the pen name '''Nigel West'''.
==Background== Born in [[London]],<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1543981/ Rupert Allason] IMDb</ref> Allason and his brother, Julian, were brought up as [[Roman Catholic]]s, the faith of their [[Irish people|Irish]] mother, Nuala McElveen (who acted under the name Nuala Barrie), and attended [[Downside School]]. Their father, [[James Allason]], was also a Conservative Party MP.
==Political career== Rupert Allason contested [[Kettering (UK Parliament constituency)|Kettering]] in [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979]] and [[Battersea (UK Parliament constituency)|Battersea]] in [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983]] before being elected as Conservative MP for Torbay in 1987.
He was opposed to ceding greater power to [[European Union|Brussels]], in 1993 he was the only [[Tory]] who refused to vote for the [[Maastricht Treaty]] when it was made into a [[1993 vote of confidence in the government of John Major|motion of confidence]]. The vote was narrowly won but Allason's abstention caused him to have the [[party whip]] withdrawn for a year.<ref name="bbc-no-stranger">{{cite news |title=Rupert Allason: No stranger to the courtroom |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/1604713.stm |publisher = BBC News |date = 17 October 2001 |accessdate = 20 August 2006 | quote= As John Major's prime ministership lurched from crisis to crisis, every MP's vote counting as the tiny Conservative parliamentary majority dwindled away after 1992, Mr Allason rebelled over Maastricht and then became the only Tory to refuse to back his government in a no confidence motion. }}</ref> He left parliament after the landslide [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 general election]], when he lost his seat to [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] [[Adrian Sanders]].<ref>{{cite web |title = General election results in Torbay, 1997 and 2001 |url = http://www.psr.keele.ac.uk/area/uk/constit/242.htm |publisher = Richard Kimber |work = Political Science Resources |accessdate = 11 October 2007}}</ref> He is widely considered to have lost because he failed to tip a pub waitress a week before polling day. As a consequence, fourteen waiters who were going to vote for Allason switched to the Liberal Democrats. He lost by twelve votes.<ref>{{cite news |title = A guide to life in a marginal constituency |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-25664580 |publisher = BBC News |date = 9 January 2015 |accessdate = 9 January 2015}}</ref>
In 2000, Allason was reported to have considered joining the [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP).<ref>{{cite news |title = Tory Euro-sceptic considers defection |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/596381.stm |publisher = BBC News |date = 9 January 2000 |accessdate = 11 October 2007}}</ref> The author [[Jon Ronson]] in the first chapter of his book ''[[Them: Adventures With Extremists]]'' briefly analyses Allason's career and character, with particular emphasis on his 1997 electoral loss.
==Literary career== {{unsourced|section|date=August 2017}} As an author, Allason has concentrated on security and intelligence issues and his controversial books have frequently made headlines. He was voted 'The Experts' Expert' by a panel of other spy writers in ''[[The Observer]]'' in November 1989. In 1984 ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]]'' commented: "His information is so precise that many people believe he is the unofficial historian of the secret services. West's sources are undoubtedly excellent. His books are peppered with deliberate clues to potential front-page stories."
Allason has been a frequent speaker at intelligence seminars and has lectured at both the [[KGB]] headquarters in Dzerzhinsky Square, [[Moscow]] and at the [[CIA]] headquarters in [[Langley, Virginia|Langley]], Virginia, where he once addressed an audience that included the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] spy [[Aldrich Ames]]. He continues to lecture to members of the intelligence community at the Centre for Counterintelligence and Security Studies in [[Washington, D.C.]]
His special contribution to the study of modern historical espionage has been in tracking down former agents and persuading them to tell their stories. He traced the wartime double agent [[Joan Pujol Garcia|GARBO]], who was reported to have died in [[Africa]] in 1949. However, Allason found him in [[Venezuela]], and they collaborated on the book ''Operation Garbo'', published in 1985.
He was also the first person to identify and interview the mistress of [[Admiral Canaris]], the German intelligence chief who headed the [[Abwehr]], and he was responsible for the exposure of Leo Long and Edward Scott as Soviet spies.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
His titles include ''The Crown Jewels'', based on files made available to him by the [[KGB]] archives in Moscow; ''VENONA'', which disclosed the existence of a [[GRU]] spy-ring operating in London throughout the war, allegedly headed by [[J. B. S. Haldane|Professor JBS Haldane]] and [[Ivor Montagu|the Hon. Ivor Montagu]]; and ''The Third Secret'', an account of the CIA's intervention in [[Afghanistan]]. ''Mortal Crimes'', published in September 2004, investigates the scale of Soviet espionage in the [[Manhattan Project]], the Anglo-American development of an [[atomic bomb]].
In 2005 he edited ''The Guy Liddell Diaries'', a daily journal of the wartime work of [[MI5]]'s Director of Counter-Espionage. He also published a study of the [[Comintern]]'s secret wireless traffic, ''MASK: MI5's Penetration of the Communist Party of Great Britain'', and the first of a series of counter-intelligence textbooks, ''The Historical Dictionary of British Intelligence'', ''The Historical Dictionary of International Intelligence'' and ''The Historical Dictionary of Cold War Counter-Intelligence''.
==Legal actions== Allason has been involved in a number of legal cases, in each of which he represented himself [[pro se|without lawyers]]. While in the House of Commons, he campaigned against the use of [[Public Interest Immunity|Public Interest Immunity Certificates]], and exposed the arms-dealing activities of the billionaire publisher [[Robert Maxwell]]. He was sued for libel by Maxwell but won the case, winning record damages for a litigant in person by counterclaim.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}}
In 1996 Allason sued [[Alastair Campbell]] for malicious falsehood with regard to an article printed in the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' in November 1992. The case was heard by Mr Justice Drake, without a jury. The judge ruled that Allason had failed to demonstrate that the ''Daily Mirror'' article, although inaccurate, had caused him any financial loss.<ref>{{cite news|title=Campbell denies control freak claim|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/uk/138291.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=23 July 1998|accessdate=11 October 2007}}</ref><ref name="BBC-1998-23-07">{{cite news|title=Rupert Allason wins case against Alastair Campbell, PM's aide|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/142548.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=30 July 1998|accessdate=11 October 2007}}</ref> In a retrial in 1998, he was awarded £1,050 in damages and 75% of his legal costs.<ref name="BBC-1998-23-07"/>
In 1998, he brought and lost a libel action against the [[BBC]] show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' over comments made in a book based on the show published in 1996 that "given Mr Allason's fondness for pursuing libel actions, there are also excellent legal reasons for not referring to him as a conniving little shit."<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-Tory MP loses libel action|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/49430.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=21 January 1998|accessdate=20 August 2006}}</ref>
In 2001 Allason sued [[Random House]], the publishers of ''The Enigma Spy'', the autobiography of the former Soviet agent [[John Cairncross]]. Allason claimed he had [[ghost writer|ghostwritten]] ''The Enigma Spy'' in return for the copyright and 50 per cent of the proceeds. However, Allason lost the case and was ordered to pay costs of around £200,000. In passing judgment the trial judge said that Allason was "a profoundly dishonest man" and "one of the most dishonest witnesses I have ever seen".<ref>{{cite news|title=Former Tory MP 'profoundly dishonest'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/1602821.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=16 October 2001|accessdate=20 August 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Spy writer branded a liar by judge faces prosecution|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1359641/Spy-writer-branded-a-liar-by-judge-faces-prosecution.html|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|work=The Telegraph|date=16 October 2001|accessdate=11 October 2007| first=Sean|last=O'Neill|location=London, UK}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Lying' former Tory MP faces criminal charge|url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/news/articles/0,6109,575414,00.html|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=17 October 2001|accessdate=11 October 2007|first=Richard|last=Norton-Taylor|location=London}}</ref>
In September 2005, Allason was threatened with prison for [[contempt of court]] in relation to paying the damages from the 2001 case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spywriter Tory may join Aitken and Archer out in the cold|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article310187.ece|publisher=The Independent|date=4 September 2005|accessdate=11 October 2007|first1=Andy|last1=McSmith|first2=Steve|last2=Bloomfield|location=London, UK|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930191122/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/legal/article310187.ece|archivedate=30 September 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Spy writer faces jail for refusing to reveal assets|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/spy-writer-faces-jail-for-refusing-to-reveal-assets-657730.html|publisher=The Independent|date=20 April 2002|accessdate=24 July 2009|first=Steve|last=Boggan|location=London, UK|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108083944/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/spy-writer-faces-jail-for-refusing-to-reveal-assets-657730.html|archivedate=8 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=UK news in brief: Sentence for spy writer|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/sep/03/1|publisher=Guardian News and Media|work=The Guardian|date=3 September 2005|accessdate=9 June 2012|location=London, UK}}</ref>
==Honours and awards== Allason is the recipient of the U.S. Association of Former Intelligence Officers (AFIO)'s Lifetime Literature Achievement Award, and in 2011 he was elected to the Honorary Board of that association. He is the European Editor of the ''World Intelligence Review'', published in [[Washington D.C.]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Contact Us|publisher=World Intelligence Review|url=http://www.theworldintelligencereview.com/contact.html|accessdate=11 October 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070120220243/http://www.theworldintelligencereview.com/contact.html|archivedate=20 January 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
== Personal life == In 1979 Allason married Nikki van Moppes. They divorced in 1996 shortly after Allason was exposed by UK tabloid papers for having an extramarital tryst at [[Sandy Lane Hotel]] in [[Barbados]]. The couple have two children, the elder of whom is entrepreneur [[Tom Allason]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-399571/Wealth-women-mobile-phone-king.html | work=Mail Online|publisher=Associated Newspapers | title=Wealth, women and the mobile phone king | date=8 August 2006 | first=Simon | last=Moon | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20011017/ai_n14422341 | title=Rebel without a case "profoundly dishonest" | work = The Independent }} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/uk/49430.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ex-Tory MP loses libel action | date=21 January 1998 | accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref> In July 2012, Rupert Allason became engaged to violinist [[Nicola Loud]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/9427610/Spy-author-Rupert-Allason-seduces-Loud-musician.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Spy author Rupert Allason seduces Loud musician | date=26 July 2012}}</ref>
In the 1970s, Allason began practising [[Transcendental Meditation technique|Transcendental Meditation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jail term threat to former Tory MP |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/jail-term-threat-to-former-tory-mp-1-503891 |website=The Scotsman |accessdate=6 November 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TsuVldnk?url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/jail-term-threat-to-former-tory-mp-1-503891 |archivedate=6 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Publications== *''Spy!'' (by Richard Deacon with Nigel West), London: British Broadcasting Corporation, 1980 *''MI5: British Security Service Operations, 1909–1945'', New York: Stein and Day, 1982, 1981 *''A Matter of Trust: MI5, 1945–72'', London: [[Weidenfeld and Nicolson]], 1982; published in the U.S. as ''The Circus: MI5, Operations 1945–1972'', New York : Stein and Day, 1983 *''MI6: British Secret Intelligence Service Operations: 1909–45'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1983 *''Unreliable Witness: Espionage Myths of the Second World War'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1984 *''The Branch: A History of the Metropolitan Police Special Branch'' (By Rupert Allason) *''Operation Garbo: The Personal Story of the Most Successful Double Agent of World War II'', co-written by [[Juan Pujol]] and Nigel West, London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1985 *''GCHQ: The Secret Wireless War, 1900–86'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1986, {{ISBN|0-297-78717-9}} *''Molehunt: The Full Story of the Soviet Spy in MI5'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1987 *''The Friends: Britain's Post-War Secret Intelligence operations'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1988 *''Games of Intelligence: The Classified Conflict of International Espionage'', London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1989 *''The Blue List'' (novel), London: Secker & Warburg, 1989, {{ISBN|0-436-56602-8}} *''Cuban Bluff'' (novel), London: Secker & Warburg, War Whitehall Nearly Lost'': Little Brown, January 1997, {{ISBN|0-7515-2071-3}} *''The Faber Book of Treachery'': Faber & Faber, March 1998 *''The Crown Jewels: The British Secrets Exposed by the KGB {{ISBN|0-00-653071-0}} *''The Third Secret: The CIA, Solidarity and the KGB's Plot to Kill the Pope'': HarperCollins, October 2000 *''Mortal Crimes: The Greatest Theft in History: Soviet Penetration
